\begin{center}
\title[Varieties of apolar subschemes of toric surfaces]
{Varieties of apolar subschemes of toric surfaces}
\par \bigskip
\author[M.~Gallet]{Matteo Gallet}
\address{RICAM, Austrian Academy of Sciences, Altenberger Stra{\ss}e 69, A-4040, Linz, Austria.}
\email{matteo.gallet@ricam.oeaw.ac.at}
\author[K.~Ranestad]{Kristian Ranestad}
\address{University of Oslo, Department of Mathematics, PO Box 1053, Blindern, N-0316 Oslo, Norway}
\email{ranestad@math.uio.no}
\author[N.~Villamizar]{Nelly Villamizar}
\address{RICAM, Austrian Academy of Sciences, Altenberger Stra{\ss}e 69, A-4040, Linz, Austria.}
\email{nelly.villamizar@oeaw.ac.at}
\keywords{toric surfaces, apolarity, apolar schemes, powersum varieties.}
\subjclass[2000]{14C99,14M99}

\date{\today}
\maketitle
\end{center}

\begin{abstract}
Powersum varieties, also called varieties of sums of powers, have provided 
examples of interesting relations between varieties since their first 
appearance in the 19th century. One of the most useful tools to study them 
is apolarity, a notion originally related to the action of differential 
operators on the polynomial ring. In this work we make explicit how one can 
see apolarity in terms of the Cox ring of a variety. In this way powersum 
varieties are a special case of varieties of apolar schemes; we 
explicitely describe examples of such varieties in the case of two toric 
surfaces, when the Cox ring is particularly well-behaved.
\end{abstract}

\section{introduction}\label{intro}

Powersum varieties for homogeneous forms provide examples of surprising 
relations between varieties, in particular between hypersurfaces and the 
variety of expressions of the defining form as a sum of powers of linear 
forms.

These varieties have been widely studied since the 19th century: Sylvester 
considered and solved the case of binary forms (see \cites{Sylvester1904a, Sylvester1904b}). 
A number of further cases have been treated more recently, see \cite {IR}, 
\cite{MM}, \cite{Muk92}, \cite{RS1}, \cite{RS2} and~\cite{RV}.


Powersum varieties are special cases of a general construction:  given a 
projective variety $X\subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^n$, 
let $y\in {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^n$ be a general point and $k$ be the minimal natural number 
such that there are  $k$ points in~$X$ whose span contains~$y$. Thus $k$ is 
the smallest integer such that the $(k-1)$-th secant variety of~$X$ fills 
the space~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^n$.

Define ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}}}_X(y,k)$ to be the closure in ${\ensuremath\mathrm{Hilb}}_k(X)$ of the set of 
smooth subschemes of length $k$ whose span contains~$y$. 
If $X$ is the $d$-uple embedding of~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^r$, then one may interpret~$y$ as 
the class~$[f]$ of a 
homogeneous form~$f$ of degree~$d$.  The $k$-tuples of points on~$X$ whose 
span contains $[f]$ represent expressions of~$f$ as a sum of $d$-th powers 
of linear forms.  The closure of this set of $k$-tuples in the Hilbert 
scheme is denoted~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}}}(f,k)$ and coincides with the variety~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}}}_X(f,k)$.

The notion ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}}}_X(y,k)$ can be read as ``Variety of aPolar Subschemes": 
 \begin{definition}
 A subscheme $Z \subseteq X$ is called apolar to $y\in {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^n$, if $y$ is contained in the  linear span of $Z$ in  ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^n$.
 \end{definition}
 Note that ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}}}_X(y,k)$ contains only those apolar subschemes that are in the closure of the set of smooth apolar subschemes.  
 When $\dim X>3$, then the general point~$y$ may have singular apolar subschemes of length~$k$ that do not belong to this closure.
 
Apolar schemes have been studied (in the classical setting of 
powersum varieties) considering the ideal, in the polynomial ring, of 
differential operators annihilating a given homogeneous form. 
In this paper we generalize this approach to the general setting of the 
${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}}}$, using the Cox ring of~$X$, the graded ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{C}}}$-algebra of 
sections of all line bundles on~$X$, graded by the Picard group~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{Pic}}}(X)$.
When $X$ is a toric variety, the Cox ring is a polynomial ring (see~\cite{Cox}).

Let $S$ and $T$  be two copies of the Cox ring of $X$, with grading given by 
the Picard group ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{Pic}}}(X)$.  
 For each element $A \in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{Pic}}}(X)$ we let $S_A$ be the space of linear forms 
on $T_A$.   For each nonzero $f\in S_A$ we let $H_f \subseteq T_A$ be the 
hyperplane of sections that vanish at the point $[f]\in {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}(S_A)$. In the 
classical setting of powersum varieties, $H_{f}$ is a hyperplane of 
differential operators annihilating $f$.

 If $A$ is very 
ample on $X$, then its global sections $T_A$ define the embedding $\nu_A: X \hookrightarrow {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}(S_A)$. Thus $T_A$ is the space of linear 
forms on ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}(S_A)$.  For a subscheme $Z \subseteq X\subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}(S_A)$ we set

\end{definition}

Notice that for a bihomogeneous form~$f\in S_{a,b}$ one has $f_{a,b}^\bot = H_f$, 
where $H_f$  is the hyperplane defined in Section~\ref{intro}. Moreover, 
$f_{c,d}^\bot = f_{a,b}^\bot \colon T_{(a-c, b-d)}$ for all $c {\leqslant} a$ and $d 
{\leqslant} b$. This shows that $f^\bot = I_f$, where $I_f$ is the ideal defined in 
Section~\ref{intro}. 
The maps~$\phi_{f,(a,b)}$ from Equation~\eqref{apolarmap} are in this case given
by applying the elements of~$T$ as differential operators to $f$. It follows that 
$\ker \phi_{f,(a,b)}$  is the set of forms of bidegree~$(a,b)$ in~$f^\bot$, namely 
$f_{a,b}^\bot$.

In the case of ${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$, every divisor of class $(a,b)$ with $a,b>0$ 
is very ample and determines the Segre-Veronese embedding

\end{definition}

We can give a geometric description of~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{rank}}}(f)$ as follows. 
Identifying ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{ ab + a + b }$ with~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}} \left( S_{a,b} \right)$,
we can associate to every form $f \in S_{a,b}$ a point $[f] \in {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{ab+a+b}$.
In this way, the forms in~$S_{a,b}$ of rank~$1$ correspond to points
lying on the Segre-Veronese variety. 
Moreover, a form has rank~$r$ if and only if it lies in the span of exactly 
(not less than) $r$ points in the Segre-Veronese.

The previous interpretation connects the rank of bihomogeneous forms 
with the theory of secant varieties of the Segre-Veronese. In particular,
a general bihomogeneous form in~$S_{a,b}$ has rank~$r$ if and only if
the $r$-secant variety coincides with ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{ab+a+b}$.

The computation of the dimension of secant varieties carried by Catalisano, 
Geramita and Gimigliano in~\cite{CGG2005a}*{Corollary 2.3}, implies that if $f$ 
is a bihomogeneous \emph{general} form of bidegree~$(a,b)$, then

nexttext:
Let ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{U}}}$ be the open subset of~$\mathcal{H}$ parametrizing zero-dimensional
schemes given by~$r$ distinct points in ${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$. 
Then for every $[\Gamma] \in {\ensuremath{\mathcal{U}}}$ we have that $\Gamma = (P_1, \dotsc, P_r)$. Also,  it is possible to restrict~${\ensuremath{\mathcal{U}}}$ so that the $(a,b)$-th powers of 
all linear forms associated to the points $P_i$'s are linearly independent. 
In this way we can prove that $\pi_1$ is dominant. Moreover, if $[\Gamma] \in 
{\ensuremath{\mathcal{U}}}$, then the fiber of~$\pi_1$ over~$[\Gamma]$ is an open set of a linear 
space of dimension~$r-1$. Since $\mathcal{H}$ is irreducible and 
nonsingular (see~\cite{Fogarty1968}), then also~$\mathcal{X}$ is irreducible 
and of dimension~$3r-1$. The fiber of~$\pi_2$ over $[f] \in {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{ab +a +b}$ 
is~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,r)$, so we get that for a general~$f$, the variety ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,r)$ has 
dimension $3r-1-(ab+a+b)$. Using Equation~\eqref{eq:rankf} the statement follows.
\end{proof}

If $f$ is a general bihomogeneous form in~$S_{2,2}$, then by 
Equation~\eqref{eq:rankf} applied to the case $(a,b) = (2,2d)$ 
with~$d=1$, the rank of~$f$ is~$4$, hence $\dim {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}} (f, 4) = 3$
by Proposition~\ref{prop:dimension}.
In order to study the geometry of this variety we use apolarity. 

\begin{lemma}
\label{lem:orthogonal_biquadratic}
For a general form $f\in S_{2,2}$ the orthogonal~$f^\bot$ is generated 
by~$f_{2,1}^\bot, f_{1,2}^\bot, f_{3,0}^\bot$ and 
$f_{0,3}^\bot$. Moreover, both $f^{\bot}_{2,1}$ and $f^{\bot}_{1,2}$ have dimension~$4$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof} 
Since $\dim T_{2,1} = 6$ and $\dim S_{0,1} = 2$, and $f$ is general, the 
kernel~$f_{2,1}^\bot$ of the map $\phi_{f,(2,1)}$ has dimension~$4$. By 
symmetry, also $f^\bot_{1,2}$ has dimension~$4$.

Consider the vector subspace $T_{0,1} \cdot f^{\bot}_{2,1} \subseteq
f^{\bot}_{2,2}$: if it is of dimension~$8$, it means that we do not need 
elements from~$f^{\bot}_{2,2}$ to generate $f^{\bot}$. 
Suppose that $\dim T_{0,1} \cdot f^{\bot}_{2,1} < 8$: if $g_1, \dotsc, g_4$ 
is a basis for~$f^{\bot}_{2,1}$, then $u_0 {\thinspace} g_1, \dotsc, u_0 {\thinspace} g_4$, 
$u_1 {\thinspace} g_1, \dotsc, u_1 {\thinspace} g_4$ are not linearly independent. So,
 for some $h_1, h_2 \in f^{\bot}_{2,1}$ we have 
$u_0 {\thinspace} h_1 + u_1 {\thinspace} h_2 = 0$. This 
implies that there exists a nonzero $\tilde{h} \in T_{0,2}$ such that $h_1 = 
u_1 {\thinspace} \tilde{h}$ and $-h_2 = u_0 \tilde{h}$. Hence $T_{0,1} \cdot \tilde{h} 
\subseteq f^{\bot}$, which forces $\tilde{h} \in f^{\bot}$. But $\tilde{h}$ has 
bidegree~$(2,0)$, and by the generality assumption on~$f$ there is no nontrivial 
element in~$f^{\bot}_{2,0}$. Hence $\dim T_{0,1} \cdot f^{\bot}_{2,1} = 8$, and so 
$T_{0,1} \cdot f^{\bot}_{2,1} = f^{\bot}_{2,2}$.

Moreover, since $f$ is a form of bidegree $(2,2)$, then $f^{\bot}_{a,b} = T_{
a,b}$ whenever~$a$ or~$b$ is greater than or equal to~$3$. Notice that $T_{3
,b} = T_{3,0}\cdot T_{0,b}$, and $T_{a,3} =  T_{0,3} \cdot T _{a,0}$, for 
every $a, b{\geqslant} 1$. Thus, $f^\bot_{2,1}$, $f^\bot_{1,2}$ together with 
$f^\bot_{3,0} = T_{3,0}$ and $f^\bot_{0,3} = T_{0,3}$ generate the 
ideal~$f^\bot$. 
\end{proof}

The space of sections $f^{\bot}_{2,1}$ define a linear system of $(2,1)$-curves on~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ and, 
by Lemma~\ref{lem:orthogonal_biquadratic}, a rational map $\delta_{2,1} \colon 
{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}} \longrightarrow {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ fitting in the diagram
prevtext:
Let ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{U}}}$ be the open subset of~$\mathcal{H}$ parametrizing zero-dimensional
schemes given by~$r$ distinct points in ${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$. 
Then for every $[\Gamma] \in {\ensuremath{\mathcal{U}}}$ we have that $\Gamma = (P_1, \dotsc, P_r)$. Also,  it is possible to restrict~${\ensuremath{\mathcal{U}}}$ so that the $(a,b)$-th powers of 
all linear forms associated to the points $P_i$'s are linearly independent. 
In this way we can prove that $\pi_1$ is dominant. Moreover, if $[\Gamma] \in 
{\ensuremath{\mathcal{U}}}$, then the fiber of~$\pi_1$ over~$[\Gamma]$ is an open set of a linear 
space of dimension~$r-1$. Since $\mathcal{H}$ is irreducible and 
nonsingular (see~\cite{Fogarty1968}), then also~$\mathcal{X}$ is irreducible 
and of dimension~$3r-1$. The fiber of~$\pi_2$ over $[f] \in {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{ab +a +b}$ 
is~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,r)$, so we get that for a general~$f$, the variety ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,r)$ has 
dimension $3r-1-(ab+a+b)$. Using Equation~\eqref{eq:rankf} the statement follows.
\end{proof}

We are left with the case when the pencil $\left\langle g_1, g_2 
\right\rangle$ has a $(0,1)$ curve $\ell$ in its base locus. Consider the 
maps in the diagram~(\ref{eq:delta}), with $L_{2,1}$ the center 
of the projection~$\pi_{2,1}$. Then $\ell$ is sent to a conic by~$\eta_{2,1}$. 
Hence there is a pencil of hyperplanes in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$ passing through~$L_{2,1}$ 
and having a conic in its base locus. Since the base locus of a pencil 
of hyperplanes in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$ is a $3$-dimensional linear space, both the conic 
and the line~$L_{2,1}$ lie in a~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$. The latter happens if and only if 
$L_{2,1}$ intersects the plane spanned by such a conic, but this is not

The image $Z_{2,1}$ of~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ under the map~$\delta_{2,1}$ is a rational scroll, since it is 
rational and covered by the images of the lines in the scroll $\eta_{2,1} \left( {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}} \right)$.
In the following we describe its singular locus.  

\begin{lemma}\label{lem:singular_locus}
$Z_{2,1}$ is a quartic surface 
in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ that has double points along a twisted cubic curve and no triple points. 
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
A scheme~$z$ of length~$3$ in~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ is contained in a $(1,1)$-curve $C$, 
so if $z$ is mapped to a point by $\delta_{2,1}=\pi_{2,1}\circ \eta_{2,1}$ 
the projection center~$L_{2,1}$ is contained in the span of $z \subseteq Y_{2,1}$, and hence in the
span of the image of~$C$ in~$Y_{2,1}$. But then $C$ is mapped to a line in~$Z_{2,1}$, excluded by Corollary~\ref{cor:morphism}.
Therefore $Z_{2,1}$ has no triple points.
A general plane section of~$Z_{2,1}$ is the image of a 
smooth rational quartic curve in~$Y_{2,1}$. Therefore a general plane 
section of~$Z$ is a rational quartic curve, and therefore has $3$ singular points 
that span a plane, hence~$\operatorname{Sing}\left( Z_{2,1} \right)$ spans~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ 
and is a cubic curve. From the double point formula (see~\cite{fulton1998}*{Theorem~9.3}) 
we see that the double point locus of the restriction~$\pi|_{{Y_{2,1}}}$ 
is a curve on~$Y_{2,1}$ of degree~$6$ because it is linearly 
equivalent to $-K_{Y_{2,1}}$ (the anticanonical divisor of~$Y_{2,1}$). If~$\,\operatorname{Sing}\left( Z_{2,1} \right)$ is not a twisted cubic, then it 
has to contain a line. The preimage under~$\pi$ of such a line is then 
either a conic~$C$ or two skew lines~$E_1$ and $E_2$. In the first case the 
center~$L_{2,1}$ of~$\pi_{2,1}$ intersects~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}(C)$, but this is not 
possible because of Lemma~\ref{lem:partials_22}. In the second case we have 
$L_{2,1} \subseteq {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} (E_1 \cup E_2)$. Since ${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} (E_1 \cup E_2) \cong 
{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$, there is a pencil of hyperplanes in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$ containing it; each of 
them intersects~$X$ in~$E_1 \cup E_2$ and in a residual conic~$D$. Hence we 
obtain a pencil of conics~$D$ such that ${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}(D)$ intersects~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} (E_1 \cup
 E_2)$ in a line~$F$. In this way we get a pencil of lines~$F$ in~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} (E_1
 \cup E_2)$; such pencil fills a quadric in~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} (E_1 \cup E_2)$, and 
therefore the center~$L$ intersects this quadric in $2$ points; this 
situation is again ruled out by Lemma~\ref{lem:partials_22}. Therefore the 
only possibility left is that $\operatorname{Sing}\left( Z_{2,1} \right)$ 
is a twisted cubic.
\end{proof}

\begin{remark}
\label{remark:collinear}
Consider  a smooth scheme  $[\Gamma] \in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$ apolar to~$f$, namely 
${\ensuremath{\mathnormal{I}}}_{\Gamma}\subseteq f^\bot$. Notice that the dimension of~$I_{\Gamma, (2,1)}$
 equals the number of linearly independent planes in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ passing 
through~$\delta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$. Moreover $2 {\leqslant} \dim I_{\Gamma, (2,1)} {\leqslant} 3$, 
where the latter inequality follows since $\delta_{2,1}$ is defined on the 
whole~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$. However, Lemma~\ref{lem:singular_locus} excludes that the 
dimension of~$I_{\Gamma, (2,1)}$ is~$3$, since in that case we would have 
that $\delta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ is a point. Therefore $\dim I_{\Gamma, (2,1)} =2$ and
$\delta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ spans a line.
\end{remark}

common $(1,1)$ curve, then $f^{\bot}_{1,1}$ would be non-trivial and this again

We are left with the case when the pencil $\left\langle g_1, g_2 
\right\rangle$ has a $(0,1)$ curve $\ell$ in its base locus. Consider the 
maps in the diagram~(\ref{eq:delta}), with $L_{2,1}$ the center 
of the projection~$\pi_{2,1}$. Then $\ell$ is sent to a conic by~$\eta_{2,1}$. 
Hence there is a pencil of hyperplanes in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$ passing through~$L_{2,1}$ 
and having a conic in its base locus. Since the base locus of a pencil 
of hyperplanes in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$ is a $3$-dimensional linear space, both the conic 
and the line~$L_{2,1}$ lie in a~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$. The latter happens if and only if 
$L_{2,1}$ intersects the plane spanned by such a conic, but this is not 
possible by Corollary~\ref{cor:morphism}.
\end{proof}

The image $Z_{2,1}$ of~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ under the map~$\delta_{2,1}$ is a rational scroll, since it is 
rational and covered by the images of the lines in the scroll $\eta_{2,1} \left( {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}} \right)$.
In the following we describe its singular locus.  

\begin{lemma}\label{lem:singular_locus}
$Z_{2,1}$ is a quartic surface 
in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ that has double points along a twisted cubic curve and no triple points. 
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
A scheme~$z$ of length~$3$ in~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ is contained in a $(1,1)$-curve $C$, 
so if $z$ is mapped to a point by $\delta_{2,1}=\pi_{2,1}\circ \eta_{2,1}$ 
the projection center~$L_{2,1}$ is contained in the span of $z \subseteq Y_{2,1}$, and hence in the
span of the image of~$C$ in~$Y_{2,1}$. But then $C$ is mapped to a line in~$Z_{2,1}$, excluded by Corollary~\ref{cor:morphism}.
Therefore $Z_{2,1}$ has no triple points.
A general plane section of~$Z_{2,1}$ is the image of a 
smooth rational quartic curve in~$Y_{2,1}$. Therefore a general plane 
section of~$Z$ is a rational quartic curve, and therefore has $3$ singular points 
that span a plane, hence~$\operatorname{Sing}\left( Z_{2,1} \right)$ spans~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ 
and is a cubic curve. From the double point formula (see~\cite{fulton1998}*{Theorem~9.3}) 
we see that the double point locus of the restriction~$\pi|_{{Y_{2,1}}}$ 
is a curve on~$Y_{2,1}$ of degree~$6$ because it is linearly 
equivalent to $-K_{Y_{2,1}}$ (the anticanonical divisor of~$Y_{2,1}$). If~$\,\operatorname{Sing}\left( Z_{2,1} \right)$ is not a twisted cubic, then it 
has to contain a line. The preimage under~$\pi$ of such a line is then 
either a conic~$C$ or two skew lines~$E_1$ and $E_2$. In the first case the 
center~$L_{2,1}$ of~$\pi_{2,1}$ intersects~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}(C)$, but this is not 
possible because of Lemma~\ref{lem:partials_22}. In the second case we have 
$L_{2,1} \subseteq {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} (E_1 \cup E_2)$. Since ${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} (E_1 \cup E_2) \cong 
{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$, there is a pencil of hyperplanes in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$ containing it; each of 
them intersects~$X$ in~$E_1 \cup E_2$ and in a residual conic~$D$. Hence we 
obtain a pencil of conics~$D$ such that ${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}(D)$ intersects~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} (E_1 \cup
 E_2)$ in a line~$F$. In this way we get a pencil of lines~$F$ in~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} (E_1
 \cup E_2)$; such pencil fills a quadric in~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} (E_1 \cup E_2)$, and 
therefore the center~$L$ intersects this quadric in $2$ points; this 
situation is again ruled out by Lemma~\ref{lem:partials_22}. Therefore the 
only possibility left is that $\operatorname{Sing}\left( Z_{2,1} \right)$ 
is a twisted cubic.
\end{proof}

\begin{remark}
\label{remark:collinear}
Consider  a smooth scheme  $[\Gamma] \in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$ apolar to~$f$, namely 
${\ensuremath{\mathnormal{I}}}_{\Gamma}\subseteq f^\bot$. Notice that the dimension of~$I_{\Gamma, (2,1)}$
 equals the number of linearly independent planes in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ passing 
through~$\delta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$. Moreover $2 {\leqslant} \dim I_{\Gamma, (2,1)} {\leqslant} 3$, 
where the latter inequality follows since $\delta_{2,1}$ is defined on the 
whole~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$. However, Lemma~\ref{lem:singular_locus} excludes that the 
dimension of~$I_{\Gamma, (2,1)}$ is~$3$, since in that case we would have 
that $\delta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ is a point. Therefore $\dim I_{\Gamma, (2,1)} =2$ and
$\delta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ spans a line.
\end{remark}

\begin{lemma}\label{lem:map22}
 For a general bihomogeneous form~$f$ of bidegree~$(2,2)$, the rational 
map~$\Phi_{2,1}$ in Equation~\eqref{eq:birational_22} extends to a morphism on the 
whole ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$. Moreover, the fiber over a point~$p$ under~$\Phi_{2,1}$ is a 
smooth rational curve if $p \in D_{2,1}$ and it is at most one point when $p \not\in 
D_{2,1}$. In particular, $\Phi_{2,1}$ is birational.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Since being collinear (see Remark \ref{remark:collinear}) is a closed 
property, $\Phi_{2,1}$ extends to the closure of smooth apolar schemes, namely to~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$. 

Let $[\Gamma] \in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$ and let $\ell_{\Gamma}$ be the line in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ 
containing $\delta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$. If $[\ell_{\Gamma}] \not\in D_{2,1}$, then 
$\ell_{\Gamma} \cap Z_{2,1}$ is a scheme of length~$4$, namely it is 
$\delta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$. Hence the fiber over $\ell_{\Gamma}$ is exactly~$[\Gamma]$. 
Therefore, if $\ell \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ is any line not contained 
in~$Z_{2,1}$, then either $[\ell]$ is not in the image of~$\Phi_{2,1}$, or it is the 
image of exactly one scheme in~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$.

Let $\ell \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ be a line contained in~$Z_{2,1}$. Denote by~$\ell'$ 
the $(1,0)$ line in~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ such that $\delta_{2,1}(\ell') = \ell$. 
Since the preimage of~$\,\operatorname{Sing}(Z_{2,1})$ under the projection is 
linearly equivalent to the anticanonical divisor of~$Y$, and so every line 
in~$Y_{2,1}$ intersects it in two points, then $\ell$ intersects $\operatorname{Sing}(Z_{2,1})$ 
in $2$ points. In fact, by Corollary~\ref{cor:morphism}, every 
line in~$Z_{2,1}$  is a projection of a line in~$Y$.  We know that the 
preimage of $\ell \cap \mathrm{Sing}(Z_{2,1})$ under~$\delta_{2,1}$ 
consists of a scheme of length $4$ that intersects $\ell'$ in a subscheme of length $2$.
Summing up, $\delta_{2,1}^{-1}
(\ell) = \ell' \cup \{z_{\ell}\}$, where $z_{\ell}$ is a scheme of length $2$ that is mapped to~$\ell$ by~$\delta_{2,1}$.

Let $\Gamma \subseteq {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ be an apolar scheme such that $\delta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ 
is contained in~$\ell$. Since $\Gamma$ has length $4$ and $\Gamma \subseteq \delta_{2,1}^{-1}
(\ell)$, then the span of $\eta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ must contain $\ell'$.
On the other hand, since $\Gamma$ is apolar to~$f$, it is 
also apolar to both $\partial f / \partial y_0$ and $\partial f / \partial y_1$. 
Therefore the span of $\eta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ contains the line that is 
the center of the projection~$\pi_{2,1}$ in Equation~\eqref{eq:delta}. This 
rules out immediately the case ${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, \Gamma \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1$ and ${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, \Gamma \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^2$, 
since in both cases the  center of the projection would intersect $Y_{2,1}$, contradicting Corollary~\ref{cor:morphism}.
Hence $\eta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ spans a~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^ 3$ in ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$, and
therefore there is a length $2$ subscheme of~$\Gamma$ that is not contained 
in $\ell'$. Clairly, this subscheme has to coincide with $z_{\ell}$. 

Let us consider a plane in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ through~$\ell$. By construction of the map~$\ell$, 
such plane defines (up to scalars) a form $g \in f^{\bot}_{2,1}$ 
that factors as $g = l {\thinspace} \tilde{g}$, where $l$ is a $(1,0)$ form whose 
vanishing locus in~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ is~$\ell'$.  If $g$ vanishes on a scheme $\Gamma$ of length $4$, that is apolar to $f$ and is mapped to $\ell$ by $\delta_{2,1}$, 
then $z_{\ell} \subseteq \Gamma$ and $\tilde{g}$ must vanish on the length $2$ subscheme $z_{\ell}$. 
In fact there is a pencil of $(1,1)$-forms vanishing on $z_{\ell}$ that together with $l$ vanish on $\Gamma$.
Therefore every subscheme in the fiber over a $\Phi_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ contains $z_{\ell}$ and is contained in the reducible curve $\ell'\cup Z(\tilde{g})$.

The set of apolar subschemes of length $4$ in $\ell'\cup Z(\tilde{g})$ are described in the following lemma.

\begin{lemma}\label{lem:2pencils}
Let $g\in f_{2,1}^\bot$ such that $g = l{\thinspace}\tilde{g}$ for forms~$l$ and~$\tilde{g}$ 
of bidegree~$(1,0)$ and~$(1,1)$ respectively. Then the zero locus~$C_g$ of~$g$ 
supports two pencils of length~$4$ apolar schemes. One pencil has a common 
subscheme of length $2$ on $Z(\tilde{g})$ and a moving subscheme of length $2$ on $Z(l)$, 
while the subschemes of the other pencil has a unique common point on $Z(l)$, and a moving subscheme of length $3$ on $Z(\tilde{g})$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
The fact that $g$ is apolar to~$f$ means that the point~$[f]$ is contained 
in the span of the $(2,2)$ embedding of~$C_g$, also denoted~$C_g$. By 
construction, $C_g$ splits as $C_g = C_1\cup C_2$ where $C_1$ is a conic 
and $C_2$ is a quartic rational normal curve.  
Notice that ${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_1 \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^2$ and ${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_2 \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^4$. Consider 
the projection from~$[f]$, denoted by $\rho \colon {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} {\thinspace} C_g \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^6 
\dashrightarrow {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$. Notice that $\rho|_{{\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}\, C_1}$  and $\rho|_{{\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}\, C_2}$
are isomorphisms, because otherwise $C_1$ or $C_2$ will be apolar to $f$ 
which contradicts Lemma \ref{lem:orthogonal_biquadratic}. Set $P$ to be the 
preimage under~$\rho$ of the line 
$\rho \bigl( {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_1 \bigr) \cap \rho \bigl( {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_2 \bigr)$, and define the 
lines $L_1 = P \cap {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_1$ and $L_2 = P \cap {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_2$. 

Let us focus on the line~$L_1$: by construction, it passes through~$Q = C_1 \cap 
C_2$, the only singularity of~$C_g$, and then intersects the conic~$C_1$ in 
another point~$T$. The line through~$[f]$ and~$T$ is contained in the plane~$P$, 
hence intersects~$L_2$ in a point~$\tilde{T}$. Since $C_2$ is a smooth rational 
quartic, the set

corresponds to the variety of sum of powers of a quartic bivariate form 
decomposed into three summands, and by Sylvester's result it is 
isomorphic to~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1$. If we pick the three points of intersection of such a 
trisecant plane with~$C_2$ and we add the point~$T$, we obtain four points 
whose span contains~$[f]$. Thus, we have constructed a~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1$ of schemes 
of length~$4$ apolar to~$f$ constituted of $3$ points lying on~$C_2$, and one common
point lying on~$C_1$.

Consider now the line~$L_2$: by construction, it passes through the 
singularity~$Q$, and it intersects the secant variety of~$C_2$ (a cubic 
threefold in~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_2$) in another point~$R$. The line through~$[f]$ and~$R$ is also 
contained in the plane~$P$, hence intersects~$L_1$ in a point~$\tilde{R}$. Since 
$R$ is in the secant variety of~$C_2$, there exist two points in~$C_2$ whose 
span contains~$R$. Moreover, there is a pencil of lines in~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_1$ passing 
through~$\tilde{R}$, that defines a pencil of length~$2$ schemes. In this way we 
produce a pencil of length~$4$ schemes apolar to~$f$, all of them having a 
length~$2$ scheme on $C_2$ in common. 
\end{proof}

To complete the proof of Lemma \ref{lem:map22} we apply Lemma \ref{lem:2pencils} to $\ell'\cup Z(\tilde{g})$.  
Only the pencil of apolar subschemes with a fixed subscheme of length~$2$ on~$Z(\tilde{g})$ is mapped to $\ell$ by $\delta_{2,1}$.
This completes the proof of Lemma \ref{lem:map22}.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}\label{lem:3pencils}
Let $g\in f_{2,1}^\bot$ such that $g = l_1{\thinspace} l_2{\thinspace} \tilde{l}$ for forms~$l_i$ 
of bidegree~$(1,0)$ and~$\tilde l$ of bidegree~$(0,1)$. Then the zero 
locus~$C_g$ of~$g$ supports three pencils of length~$4$ apolar schemes. 
Two of the three pencils are fibers of $\Phi_{2,1}$, while the third one is mapped isomorphically to a line in $G(2,f_{2,1}^{\bot})$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
The first part of the proof follows a similar argument as that in Lemma~\ref{lem:2pencils}, so 
we only provide a sketch. The $(2,2)$ embedding of~$C_g$ splits into three 
conics $C_1, C_2$ and $\tilde C$, such that  $C_1\cap \tilde C = \{Q_1\}$, 
$C_2\cap \tilde C =\{ Q_2\}$ and $C_1\cap C_2 = \emptyset$.

By projecting from~$[f]$ one can prove that there exists a plane~$P$ such that
$P \cap {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}\, C_1 =\ell_1$, $P \cap {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} (\tilde C\cup C_2 ) = \ell_2$ where 
$\ell_1, \ell_2$ are lines, and $P$ contains the line through $[f]$ and $Q_1$. 
The line $\ell_1$ meets $C_1$ in $Q$ and in another point $R_1$. The line 
through~$R_1$ and~$[f]$ meets~$\ell_2$ in a point~$T$. By a similar argument 
but projecting from $T$, we obtain a point $R_2\in C_2$ and a pencil of 
pairs of points $R_3, R_4 \in \tilde C$ such that $T$ is in~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}(\{R_2,R_3,R_4\})$. 
It follows that $[f]$ belongs to~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}(\{R_1,R_2,R_3,R_4\})$.
In this way we find a pencil of apolar schemes with $R_1$ and $R_2$ as fixed points, one on each of the curves~$C_1$ and~$C_2$, and a moving part of length on~$\tilde C$.  On $Z_{2,1}$, the curves $C_1$ and $C_2$ are mapped to lines by~$\delta_{2,1}$, while $\tilde C$ is mapped to a conic.  Their union is a plane section $Z_{2,1}$, and the apolar schemes are all collinear.  Since $R_1$ and $R_2$ clearly are mapped to the same point, this pencil of apolar schemes must be the pencil of lines through the image of $R_1$ and $R_2$.  Therefore the image of this pencil in $G(2,f_{2,1}^{\bot})$ is a line.
Two other pencils of such schemes with mobile parts
supported on $C_1$ and $C_2$ can be constructed similarly.   Each of the latter two pencils are mapped to a line in $Z_{2,1}$, namely the images of $C_1$ and $C_2$,
and are therefore, by Lemma \ref{lem:map22}, the fiber of the morphism $\Phi_{2,1}$ over a point in $D_{1,2}$.
This concludes the proof.
\end{proof}


\begin{proposition}
\label{prop:biquadratic}
For a general bihomogeneous form~$f$ of bidegree~$(2,2)$ the image of the 
map~$\Phi_{2,1}$ from Equation~\eqref{eq:birational_22} is a smooth linear section of 
the Grassmannian $G(2, f^{\bot}_{2,1})$.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Since $\dim {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}} (f,4) = 3$,  $\dim G(2,f_{2,1}^\bot) = 4$  and $\Phi_{2,1}$ is birational onto its image, the image is 
 a hypersurface~$U$ in~$G(2,f_{2,1}^\bot)$. 

The degree~$3$ 
component of the Chow group of~$G(2,f_{2,1}^\bot)$ is generated freely by one Schubert 
class $\Sigma_1$, so $[U] = d {\thinspace} \Sigma_1$ for some~$d$. The intersection of 
an $\alpha$-plane $\Sigma_{2}$ with $\Sigma_{1}$ gives the only class~$\Sigma_{3}$ 
in degree~$1$ in the Chow group. Hence $[U] \cdot \Sigma_{2} = d 
{\thinspace} \Sigma_{3}$. We prove that $d = 1$.

Let us consider the intersection of~$U$ with an 
$\alpha$-plane $\Sigma_2$. Every $\alpha$-plane in ~$G(2,f_{2,1}^\bot)$ is of the form

\begin{lemma}\label{lem:map22}
 For a general bihomogeneous form~$f$ of bidegree~$(2,2)$, the rational 
map~$\Phi_{2,1}$ in Equation~\eqref{eq:birational_22} extends to a morphism on the 
whole ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$. Moreover, the fiber over a point~$p$ under~$\Phi_{2,1}$ is a 
smooth rational curve if $p \in D_{2,1}$ and it is at most one point when $p \not\in 
D_{2,1}$. In particular, $\Phi_{2,1}$ is birational.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Since being collinear (see Remark \ref{remark:collinear}) is a closed 
property, $\Phi_{2,1}$ extends to the closure of smooth apolar schemes, namely to~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$. 

Let $[\Gamma] \in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$ and let $\ell_{\Gamma}$ be the line in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ 
containing $\delta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$. If $[\ell_{\Gamma}] \not\in D_{2,1}$, then 
$\ell_{\Gamma} \cap Z_{2,1}$ is a scheme of length~$4$, namely it is 
$\delta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$. Hence the fiber over $\ell_{\Gamma}$ is exactly~$[\Gamma]$. 
Therefore, if $\ell \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ is any line not contained 
in~$Z_{2,1}$, then either $[\ell]$ is not in the image of~$\Phi_{2,1}$, or it is the 
image of exactly one scheme in~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$.

Let $\ell \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ be a line contained in~$Z_{2,1}$. Denote by~$\ell'$ 
the $(1,0)$ line in~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ such that $\delta_{2,1}(\ell') = \ell$. 
Since the preimage of~$\,\operatorname{Sing}(Z_{2,1})$ under the projection is 
linearly equivalent to the anticanonical divisor of~$Y$, and so every line 
in~$Y_{2,1}$ intersects it in two points, then $\ell$ intersects $\operatorname{Sing}(Z_{2,1})$ 
in $2$ points. In fact, by Corollary~\ref{cor:morphism}, every 
line in~$Z_{2,1}$  is a projection of a line in~$Y$.  We know that the 
preimage of $\ell \cap \mathrm{Sing}(Z_{2,1})$ under~$\delta_{2,1}$ 
consists of a scheme of length $4$ that intersects $\ell'$ in a subscheme of length $2$.
Summing up, $\delta_{2,1}^{-1}
(\ell) = \ell' \cup \{z_{\ell}\}$, where $z_{\ell}$ is a scheme of length $2$ that is mapped to~$\ell$ by~$\delta_{2,1}$.

Let $\Gamma \subseteq {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ be an apolar scheme such that $\delta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ 
is contained in~$\ell$. Since $\Gamma$ has length $4$ and $\Gamma \subseteq \delta_{2,1}^{-1}
(\ell)$, then the span of $\eta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ must contain $\ell'$.
On the other hand, since $\Gamma$ is apolar to~$f$, it is 
also apolar to both $\partial f / \partial y_0$ and $\partial f / \partial y_1$. 
Therefore the span of $\eta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ contains the line that is 
the center of the projection~$\pi_{2,1}$ in Equation~\eqref{eq:delta}. This 
rules out immediately the case ${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, \Gamma \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1$ and ${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, \Gamma \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^2$, 
since in both cases the  center of the projection would intersect $Y_{2,1}$, contradicting Corollary~\ref{cor:morphism}.
Hence $\eta_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ spans a~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^ 3$ in ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$, and
therefore there is a length $2$ subscheme of~$\Gamma$ that is not contained 
in $\ell'$. Clairly, this subscheme has to coincide with $z_{\ell}$. 

Let us consider a plane in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ through~$\ell$. By construction of the map~$\ell$, 
such plane defines (up to scalars) a form $g \in f^{\bot}_{2,1}$ 
that factors as $g = l {\thinspace} \tilde{g}$, where $l$ is a $(1,0)$ form whose 
vanishing locus in~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ is~$\ell'$.  If $g$ vanishes on a scheme $\Gamma$ of length $4$, that is apolar to $f$ and is mapped to $\ell$ by $\delta_{2,1}$, 
then $z_{\ell} \subseteq \Gamma$ and $\tilde{g}$ must vanish on the length $2$ subscheme $z_{\ell}$. 
In fact there is a pencil of $(1,1)$-forms vanishing on $z_{\ell}$ that together with $l$ vanish on $\Gamma$.
Therefore every subscheme in the fiber over a $\Phi_{2,1}(\Gamma)$ contains $z_{\ell}$ and is contained in the reducible curve $\ell'\cup Z(\tilde{g})$.

The set of apolar subschemes of length $4$ in $\ell'\cup Z(\tilde{g})$ are described in the following lemma.

\begin{lemma}\label{lem:2pencils}
Let $g\in f_{2,1}^\bot$ such that $g = l{\thinspace}\tilde{g}$ for forms~$l$ and~$\tilde{g}$ 
of bidegree~$(1,0)$ and~$(1,1)$ respectively. Then the zero locus~$C_g$ of~$g$ 
supports two pencils of length~$4$ apolar schemes. One pencil has a common 
subscheme of length $2$ on $Z(\tilde{g})$ and a moving subscheme of length $2$ on $Z(l)$, 
while the subschemes of the other pencil has a unique common point on $Z(l)$, and a moving subscheme of length $3$ on $Z(\tilde{g})$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
The fact that $g$ is apolar to~$f$ means that the point~$[f]$ is contained 
in the span of the $(2,2)$ embedding of~$C_g$, also denoted~$C_g$. By 
construction, $C_g$ splits as $C_g = C_1\cup C_2$ where $C_1$ is a conic 
and $C_2$ is a quartic rational normal curve.  
Notice that ${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_1 \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^2$ and ${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_2 \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^4$. Consider 
the projection from~$[f]$, denoted by $\rho \colon {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} {\thinspace} C_g \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^6 
\dashrightarrow {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$. Notice that $\rho|_{{\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}\, C_1}$  and $\rho|_{{\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}\, C_2}$
are isomorphisms, because otherwise $C_1$ or $C_2$ will be apolar to $f$ 
which contradicts Lemma \ref{lem:orthogonal_biquadratic}. Set $P$ to be the 
preimage under~$\rho$ of the line 
$\rho \bigl( {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_1 \bigr) \cap \rho \bigl( {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_2 \bigr)$, and define the 
lines $L_1 = P \cap {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_1$ and $L_2 = P \cap {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_2$. 

Let us focus on the line~$L_1$: by construction, it passes through~$Q = C_1 \cap 
C_2$, the only singularity of~$C_g$, and then intersects the conic~$C_1$ in 
another point~$T$. The line through~$[f]$ and~$T$ is contained in the plane~$P$, 
hence intersects~$L_2$ in a point~$\tilde{T}$. Since $C_2$ is a smooth rational 
quartic, the set
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex24.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\bigl{\{}\mathrm{trisecant\ planes\ of\ }C_{2}\mathrm{\ passing\ through\ }%
\tilde{T}\bigr{\}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">{</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>trisecant</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>planes</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>of</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>passing</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>through</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover></mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">}</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

for a $g\in f^\bot_{2,1}$. On the other hand such a form $g$ defines a 
rational curve~$C_g$, and its $(2,2)$ embedding in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^8$ (also denoted by~$C_g$) 
has degree~$6$. Therefore, the intersection of~$U$ with $\Sigma_2(g)$
has preimage under~$\Phi_{2,1}$ given by
prevtext:
corresponds to the variety of sum of powers of a quartic bivariate form 
decomposed into three summands, and by Sylvester's result it is 
isomorphic to~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1$. If we pick the three points of intersection of such a 
trisecant plane with~$C_2$ and we add the point~$T$, we obtain four points 
whose span contains~$[f]$. Thus, we have constructed a~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1$ of schemes 
of length~$4$ apolar to~$f$ constituted of $3$ points lying on~$C_2$, and one common
point lying on~$C_1$.

Consider now the line~$L_2$: by construction, it passes through the 
singularity~$Q$, and it intersects the secant variety of~$C_2$ (a cubic 
threefold in~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_2$) in another point~$R$. The line through~$[f]$ and~$R$ is also 
contained in the plane~$P$, hence intersects~$L_1$ in a point~$\tilde{R}$. Since 
$R$ is in the secant variety of~$C_2$, there exist two points in~$C_2$ whose 
span contains~$R$. Moreover, there is a pencil of lines in~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_1$ passing 
through~$\tilde{R}$, that defines a pencil of length~$2$ schemes. In this way we 
produce a pencil of length~$4$ schemes apolar to~$f$, all of them having a 
length~$2$ scheme on $C_2$ in common. 
\end{proof}

To complete the proof of Lemma \ref{lem:map22} we apply Lemma \ref{lem:2pencils} to $\ell'\cup Z(\tilde{g})$.  
Only the pencil of apolar subschemes with a fixed subscheme of length~$2$ on~$Z(\tilde{g})$ is mapped to $\ell$ by $\delta_{2,1}$.
This completes the proof of Lemma \ref{lem:map22}.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}\label{lem:3pencils}
Let $g\in f_{2,1}^\bot$ such that $g = l_1{\thinspace} l_2{\thinspace} \tilde{l}$ for forms~$l_i$ 
of bidegree~$(1,0)$ and~$\tilde l$ of bidegree~$(0,1)$. Then the zero 
locus~$C_g$ of~$g$ supports three pencils of length~$4$ apolar schemes. 
Two of the three pencils are fibers of $\Phi_{2,1}$, while the third one is mapped isomorphically to a line in $G(2,f_{2,1}^{\bot})$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
The first part of the proof follows a similar argument as that in Lemma~\ref{lem:2pencils}, so 
we only provide a sketch. The $(2,2)$ embedding of~$C_g$ splits into three 
conics $C_1, C_2$ and $\tilde C$, such that  $C_1\cap \tilde C = \{Q_1\}$, 
$C_2\cap \tilde C =\{ Q_2\}$ and $C_1\cap C_2 = \emptyset$.

By projecting from~$[f]$ one can prove that there exists a plane~$P$ such that
$P \cap {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}\, C_1 =\ell_1$, $P \cap {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} (\tilde C\cup C_2 ) = \ell_2$ where 
$\ell_1, \ell_2$ are lines, and $P$ contains the line through $[f]$ and $Q_1$. 
The line $\ell_1$ meets $C_1$ in $Q$ and in another point $R_1$. The line 
through~$R_1$ and~$[f]$ meets~$\ell_2$ in a point~$T$. By a similar argument 
but projecting from $T$, we obtain a point $R_2\in C_2$ and a pencil of 
pairs of points $R_3, R_4 \in \tilde C$ such that $T$ is in~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}(\{R_2,R_3,R_4\})$. 
It follows that $[f]$ belongs to~${\ensuremath\mathrm{span}}(\{R_1,R_2,R_3,R_4\})$.
In this way we find a pencil of apolar schemes with $R_1$ and $R_2$ as fixed points, one on each of the curves~$C_1$ and~$C_2$, and a moving part of length on~$\tilde C$.  On $Z_{2,1}$, the curves $C_1$ and $C_2$ are mapped to lines by~$\delta_{2,1}$, while $\tilde C$ is mapped to a conic.  Their union is a plane section $Z_{2,1}$, and the apolar schemes are all collinear.  Since $R_1$ and $R_2$ clearly are mapped to the same point, this pencil of apolar schemes must be the pencil of lines through the image of $R_1$ and $R_2$.  Therefore the image of this pencil in $G(2,f_{2,1}^{\bot})$ is a line.
Two other pencils of such schemes with mobile parts
supported on $C_1$ and $C_2$ can be constructed similarly.   Each of the latter two pencils are mapped to a line in $Z_{2,1}$, namely the images of $C_1$ and $C_2$,
and are therefore, by Lemma \ref{lem:map22}, the fiber of the morphism $\Phi_{2,1}$ over a point in $D_{1,2}$.
This concludes the proof.
\end{proof}


\begin{proposition}
\label{prop:biquadratic}
For a general bihomogeneous form~$f$ of bidegree~$(2,2)$ the image of the 
map~$\Phi_{2,1}$ from Equation~\eqref{eq:birational_22} is a smooth linear section of 
the Grassmannian $G(2, f^{\bot}_{2,1})$.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Since $\dim {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}} (f,4) = 3$,  $\dim G(2,f_{2,1}^\bot) = 4$  and $\Phi_{2,1}$ is birational onto its image, the image is 
 a hypersurface~$U$ in~$G(2,f_{2,1}^\bot)$. 

The degree~$3$ 
component of the Chow group of~$G(2,f_{2,1}^\bot)$ is generated freely by one Schubert 
class $\Sigma_1$, so $[U] = d {\thinspace} \Sigma_1$ for some~$d$. The intersection of 
an $\alpha$-plane $\Sigma_{2}$ with $\Sigma_{1}$ gives the only class~$\Sigma_{3}$ 
in degree~$1$ in the Chow group. Hence $[U] \cdot \Sigma_{2} = d 
{\thinspace} \Sigma_{3}$. We prove that $d = 1$.

Let us consider the intersection of~$U$ with an 
$\alpha$-plane $\Sigma_2$. Every $\alpha$-plane in ~$G(2,f_{2,1}^\bot)$ is of the form
text:
\[
  \Sigma_2(g) = \{ \langle g_1, g_2\rangle \subseteq f_{2,1}^\bot \colon g\in \langle g_1, g_2\rangle \},
\]

\langle g_{1},g_{2}\rangle\}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>⊆</mo><msubsup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>⊥</mo></msubsup></mrow><mo>:</mo><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
If $C_g$ is smooth, then from Sylvester's result on general sextic binary forms 
(see for example~\cite{Dolgachev2012}*{Theorem~1.5.3}) we derive that $\Phi_{2,1}^{-1}\bigl(U \cap \Sigma_2(g)\bigr) \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1$. 

Consider now the case when $C_g$ is not smooth. If $C_g \subseteq {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ 
splits into the union of a line and a smooth conic (intersecting in a point), 
then $C_g \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^8$ splits into a conic~$C_1$ and a quartic~$C_2$, both 
rational and smooth.
In this case, $\Phi_{2,1}^{-1}\bigl(U \cap \Sigma_2(g)\bigr)$ has two irreducible components, 
both rational and smooth, by Lemma~\ref{lem:2pencils}.
We claim that these are the only two components of maximal dimension of the 
scheme $\Phi_{2,1}^{-1}\bigl(U \cap \Sigma_2(g)\bigr)$. In fact, if there were 
$[\Gamma] \in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$ such that $\Gamma \subseteq C_g$ and $\Gamma 
\subseteq C_1$, then the conic~$C_1$ would be apolar to~$f$. This would imply
that there is a non-zero element in~$f^{\bot}_{1,0}$, and this is not possible 
by Lemma~\ref{lem:orthogonal_biquadratic}. An analogous argument excludes the 
possibility that $\Gamma \subseteq C_2$. On the other hand, there is at 
most one scheme $\Gamma$ formed by three points on~$C_1$ and one point~$B$ 
on~$C_2$. In fact, by construction $[f] \in {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, \Gamma$, thus the 
line through~$[f]$ and~$B$ intersects ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^2 = {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_1$, so it is 
contained in the plane~$P$. Since $P \cap C_2$ is the singular point~$Q$, 
such line coincides with the line through~$[f]$ and~$Q$, and that means that we 
have at most one scheme~$\Gamma$ of this kind.

If $C_g \subseteq {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ 
splits into the union of three lines, 
then $C_g \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^8$ splits into three conics~$C_1$, $C_2$ and $\tilde C$.
In this case, $\Phi_{2,1}^{-1}\bigl(U \cap \Sigma_2(g)\bigr)$ has three irreducible 
components, all rational and smooth, but, by Lemma~\ref{lem:3pencils}, only one of them is not contracted by $\Phi_{2,1}$.

Therefore, as the $\alpha$-planes vary, we obtain a family of smooth and rational 
curves. Hence the only possibility is that $U$ is a linear complex, i.e., a 
hyperplane section of~$G(2,f_{2,1}^\bot)$. 

Let $X_{2,1}$ be the image of $\Phi_{2,1}$, we now show that $X_{2,1}$ is smooth.
For this, assume  for contradiction that $X_{2,1}$ is singular.
Then it contains two families of planes.  In particular, it contains a family of $\alpha$-planes as planes in $G\left(2, f^{\bot}_{2,1}\right)$.  But any $\alpha$-plane in $G\left(2, f^{\bot}_{2,1}\right)$ is of the form $\Sigma(g)$ and intersects $X_{2,1}$ in a curve, so cannot be contained in $X_{2,1}$.
This is a contradiction that proves that $X_{2,1}$ is smooth.
\end{proof}


\begin{proposition}
\label{prop:all_apolar}
  Every $[\Gamma] \in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$ is apolar to~$f$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
Let $[\Gamma] \in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}} (f,4)$, we have to show that $I_{\Gamma} \subseteq 
f^{\bot}$. By Lemma~\ref{lem:map22}, both $I_{\Gamma} \cap f^{\bot}_{2,1}$ 
and $I_{\Gamma} \cap f^{\bot}_{1,2}$ are two-dimensional. 
If both $I_{\Gamma, (2,1)}$ and $I_{\Gamma, (1,2)}$ are two-dimensional, then $I_{\Gamma} \subseteq 
f^{\bot}$. Suppose now that $I_{\Gamma, (2,1)}$ has dimension~$3$: 
then, by Lemma~\ref{lem:pencils_21}, the system of $(2,1)$-curves in~$I_{\Gamma} \cap f^{\bot}_{2,1}$ 
must have a common component, a $(1,0)$ line~$\ell$. 
Suppose first that $\ell$ is a common component of the whole system $I_{\Gamma, (2,1)}$.
Then the residual $3$-dimensional family of $(1,1)$ curves can have at most one point in common.
Therefore the line~$\ell$ contains a length~$3$ subscheme of~$\Gamma$. The image of~$\ell$ 
under $\delta_{1,2}$ is a conic, but this contradicts the fact that $\delta_{1,2}(\Gamma)$ is collinear. 
Suppose next that $\ell$ is not a common component of the linear system~$I_{\Gamma, (2,1)}$. Then 
$I_{\Gamma, (2,1)} = \left\langle g_1, g_2, g_3 \right\rangle$ with $g_3 \not\in I_{\Gamma} \cap f^{\bot}_{2,1}$ 
and $\ell$ and the zero locus of~$g_3$ intersect in a point. Let $g_1 = l {\thinspace} \tilde{g}_1$ and 
$g_2 = l {\thinspace} \tilde{g}_2$, where $l$ is the linear factor corresponding to $\ell$. 
Then a subscheme of length~$3$ of $\Gamma$ is contained in the zero-locus of~$\tilde{g}_1$ and~$\tilde{g}_2$. 
This forces $\tilde{g}_1$ and $\tilde{g}_2$ to have a common component~$\tilde{\ell}$, because otherwise their zero locus 
(being the intersection of two $(1,1)$ curves) have length at most $2$. Then $\tilde{\ell}$ is either 
a~$(1,0)$ or a~$(0,1)$ line. In the first case, we can repeat the previous argument and apply~$\delta_{1,2}$ 
to~$\Gamma$, obtaining a contradiction; in the second case we use~$\delta_{2,1}$.
The case with~$I_{\Gamma, (1,2)}$ is analogous.
\end{proof}
\begin{corollary}\label{22smooth} For a general bihomogeneous form~$f$ of bidegree~$(2,2)$ the variety ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}} (f,4)$ is a smooth $3$-fold.

line through~$[f]$ and~$B$ intersects ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^2 = {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, C_1$, so it is 
contained in the plane~$P$. Since $P \cap C_2$ is the singular point~$Q$, 
such line coincides with the line through~$[f]$ and~$Q$, and that means that we 
have at most one scheme~$\Gamma$ of this kind.

If $C_g \subseteq {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ 
splits into the union of three lines, 
then $C_g \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^8$ splits into three conics~$C_1$, $C_2$ and $\tilde C$.
In this case, $\Phi_{2,1}^{-1}\bigl(U \cap \Sigma_2(g)\bigr)$ has three irreducible 
components, all rational and smooth, but, by Lemma~\ref{lem:3pencils}, only one of them is not contracted by $\Phi_{2,1}$.

Therefore, as the $\alpha$-planes vary, we obtain a family of smooth and rational 
curves. Hence the only possibility is that $U$ is a linear complex, i.e., a 
hyperplane section of~$G(2,f_{2,1}^\bot)$. 

Let $X_{2,1}$ be the image of $\Phi_{2,1}$, we now show that $X_{2,1}$ is smooth.
For this, assume  for contradiction that $X_{2,1}$ is singular.
Then it contains two families of planes.  In particular, it contains a family of $\alpha$-planes as planes in $G\left(2, f^{\bot}_{2,1}\right)$.  But any $\alpha$-plane in $G\left(2, f^{\bot}_{2,1}\right)$ is of the form $\Sigma(g)$ and intersects $X_{2,1}$ in a curve, so cannot be contained in $X_{2,1}$.
This is a contradiction that proves that $X_{2,1}$ is smooth.
\end{proof}


\begin{proposition}
\label{prop:all_apolar}
  Every $[\Gamma] \in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$ is apolar to~$f$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
Let $[\Gamma] \in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}} (f,4)$, we have to show that $I_{\Gamma} \subseteq 
f^{\bot}$. By Lemma~\ref{lem:map22}, both $I_{\Gamma} \cap f^{\bot}_{2,1}$ 
and $I_{\Gamma} \cap f^{\bot}_{1,2}$ are two-dimensional. 
If both $I_{\Gamma, (2,1)}$ and $I_{\Gamma, (1,2)}$ are two-dimensional, then $I_{\Gamma} \subseteq 
f^{\bot}$. Suppose now that $I_{\Gamma, (2,1)}$ has dimension~$3$: 
then, by Lemma~\ref{lem:pencils_21}, the system of $(2,1)$-curves in~$I_{\Gamma} \cap f^{\bot}_{2,1}$ 
must have a common component, a $(1,0)$ line~$\ell$. 
Suppose first that $\ell$ is a common component of the whole system $I_{\Gamma, (2,1)}$.
Then the residual $3$-dimensional family of $(1,1)$ curves can have at most one point in common.
Therefore the line~$\ell$ contains a length~$3$ subscheme of~$\Gamma$. The image of~$\ell$ 
under $\delta_{1,2}$ is a conic, but this contradicts the fact that $\delta_{1,2}(\Gamma)$ is collinear. 
Suppose next that $\ell$ is not a common component of the linear system~$I_{\Gamma, (2,1)}$. Then 
$I_{\Gamma, (2,1)} = \left\langle g_1, g_2, g_3 \right\rangle$ with $g_3 \not\in I_{\Gamma} \cap f^{\bot}_{2,1}$ 
and $\ell$ and the zero locus of~$g_3$ intersect in a point. Let $g_1 = l {\thinspace} \tilde{g}_1$ and 
$g_2 = l {\thinspace} \tilde{g}_2$, where $l$ is the linear factor corresponding to $\ell$. 
Then a subscheme of length~$3$ of $\Gamma$ is contained in the zero-locus of~$\tilde{g}_1$ and~$\tilde{g}_2$. 
This forces $\tilde{g}_1$ and $\tilde{g}_2$ to have a common component~$\tilde{\ell}$, because otherwise their zero locus 
(being the intersection of two $(1,1)$ curves) have length at most $2$. Then $\tilde{\ell}$ is either 
a~$(1,0)$ or a~$(0,1)$ line. In the first case, we can repeat the previous argument and apply~$\delta_{1,2}$ 
to~$\Gamma$, obtaining a contradiction; in the second case we use~$\delta_{2,1}$.
The case with~$I_{\Gamma, (1,2)}$ is analogous.
\end{proof}
\begin{corollary}\label{22smooth} For a general bihomogeneous form~$f$ of bidegree~$(2,2)$ the variety ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}} (f,4)$ is a smooth $3$-fold.
\end{corollary}

Since ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$ is smooth, it suffices to complete the proof to identify the  image of~$\Xi$ and show that the image is smooth.

Now, the collection of lines  $D_{2,1} \subseteq X_{2,1}$ as defined in 
Equation~\eqref{eq:D} is a smooth rational quartic curve. It is normal, 
otherwise it would span a ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ and therefore be contained in a special 
linear complex, i.e.\ all lines in~$Z_{2,1}$ would intersect some fixed 
line, which is ruled out by Corollary~\ref{cor:morphism} above. In the 
planes spanned by two  intersecting lines in~$Z_{2,1}$ the pencil of lines 
through the intersection point is a line in~$X_{2,1}$.  For each double 
point on $Z_{2,1}$ we obtain such a line, so they form a surface scroll~$V_{2,1}
\subseteq X_{2,1}$, and by construction, $D_{2,1}$ is contained in this 
scroll, intersecting the general line in the scroll in two points. So $V_{2,1}$ 
is also contained in the secant variety of  $D_{2,1}$, a cubic 
hypersurface~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{SD}}}_{2,1}$. Therefore the scroll has degree at most $6$ and 
is contained in the complete intersection ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{SD}}}_{2,1}\cap X_{2,1}$.  To see 
that $V_{2,1}={\ensuremath{\mathrm{SD}}}_{2,1}\cap X_{2,1}$ we compute its degree.  This is 
computed from the bidegree~$(d_1,d_2)$ in the Grassmannian.  Notice that $Z_{2,1}$
parametrizes the lines in~$X_{2,1}$ that pass through a singular 
point in~$Z_{2,1}$, and that the lines in~$X_{2,1}$ that pass through a 
singular point in $Z_{2,1}$ all lie in a plane spanned by the two lines 
in~$Z_{2,1}$ that pass through the singular point. The number~$d_1$ counts the 
number of lines in a general plane that belong to~$V_{2,1}$. A general 
plane contains three singular points, and one line through each of these 
lie in the plane, so $d_1=3$. The number $d_2$ counts the number of lines 
through a general point that belong to $V_{2,1}$. A general point lies in 
three planes that intersect~$Z_{2,1}$ in a conic sections, hence also in 
two lines, so also $d_2=3$.  We conclude that $V_{2,1}$ has degree~$6$, and 
therefore that $V_{2,1}$ is a complete intersection.  Consider now a 
Veronese surface $V\subseteq G\left(2, f^{\bot}_{2,1}\right)$ that contains~$D_{2,1}$. 
The Cremona transformation on~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$ defined by the quadrics 
in the ideal of $V$ contracts the secant variety of~$V$ to a Veronese 
surface~$V'$, while the strict transform of~$V$ is mapped to the secant 
variety of~$V'$.  The Cremona transformation restricts to a birational map

where $X' \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^4$ is a smooth quadric $3$-fold.  In fact, the restriction is 
defined by the quadrics in the ideal of $D_{2,1}$ in $X_{2,1}$.  This space 
of quadrics is $5$-dimensional, and the image is a hyperplane section~$X'$ 
of the Pl\"ucker quadric, defined by the quadratic relation between the 
quadrics in the ideal of $D_{2,1}$ in ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^4$. Consider the closure of the 
graph ${\mathcal Y}\subseteq X_{2,1}\times X' $ of the rational map~$\gamma_{2,1}$. 
The strict transform of~$D_{2,1}$ in~${\mathcal Y}$ is mapped to a 
scroll~$T'$ in~$X'$, the intersection of the secant variety of a Veronese 
surface~$V'$ with the quadric threefold~$X'$. The strict transform in~${
\mathcal Y}$ of~$V_{2,1}$ is mapped to a rational normal quartic curve~$C'$
.   
We now compare the map~$\gamma_{2,1}$ with the rational map $\rho \colon \,  
X_{2,1}\dashrightarrow X_{1,2}$.   Since $\Phi_{2,1}$ is bijective outside 
the preimage of the curve~$D_{2,1}$, the rational map $\rho$ is defined 
outside $D_{2,1}$.  On the other hand $\rho$ is not defined anywhere 
on~$D_{2,1}$.  The Picard group of~$X_{2,1}$ is generated by the hyperplane 
bundle, so the map $\rho$ must be defined by a $5$-dimensional space of 
sections in $H^0({\mathcal I}_{D_{2,1}}(d))$ for some $d$, where ${\mathcal 
I}_{D_{2,1}}$ is the sheaf of ideals of~$D_{2,1}$ on  the quadric $3$-fold $
X_{2,1}$.  To find the degree~$d$ we consider a general curve~$C$ defined 
by a section in~$f^{\bot}_{2,1}$. On the surface $Z_{2,1} \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ the 
curve~$C$ is mapped to a plane quartic curve with a linear pencil of lines 
that cut the curve in the image of schemes of length $4$ that are apolar to~$f$. 
This pencil form a line in~$X_{2,1}$ that does not intersect~$D_{2,1}$. 
Now, the image~$\overline C$ of the curve~$C$ on~$Z_{1,2}$ has degree~$5$. 
The pencil of apolar schemes of length~$4$ on~$C$ are mapped to schemes 
that are collinear also in~$Z_{1,2}$, so they define on~$\overline C$ a 
pencil of $4$-secant  lines.  Assuming $C$ is smooth, any two of these four-
secant lines are disjoint, otherwise $\overline C$ would have a plane 
section of length~$7$ or~$8$, impossible.  Therefore the pencil of $4$-
secant lines are the lines of one family of lines in a smooth quadric 
surface.  This means that the image of this pencil of lines in~$X_{1,2}$ is 
a conic, and hence the degree $d$ is 2. Since $\dim H^0({\mathcal I}_{D_{2,1}}
(2))=5$ we may conclude that the map $\rho$ coincides with~$\gamma_{2,1}$. 
Clearly $\gamma_{1,2}$ is the inverse of~$\gamma_{2,1}$, and the graph~${\mathcal Y}$ 
of~$\rho$ is the blowup of~$X_{2,1}$ along the smooth curve~$D_{2,1}$, 
so ${\mathcal Y}$ is smooth. There is a map from the graph of $
\gamma_{1,2}$ to ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$ which sends a graph point to the ideal 
generated by the two pencils, one in each Grassmannian.  Therefore  the 
graph~${\mathcal Y}$  is identified with the image~$\Xi \bigl( {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4) \bigr)$. 
The graph is smooth, so ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$ and the graph~${\mathcal Y}$ are isomorphic.
\end{proof}

We identify~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}(S_{3,3})$ with a linear subspace ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{15} \subseteq

the property that the coefficient of~$z_0^2 {\thinspace} z_3$ equals the coefficient

{\thinspace} z_3, z_1^2 {\thinspace} z_2)$, $(z_0 {\thinspace} z_2 {\thinspace} z_3, z_1 {\thinspace} z_2^2)$ and 
$(z_0 {\thinspace} z_3^2, z_1 {\thinspace} z_2 {\thinspace} z_3)$.

Given $f \in S_{3,3}$ we can associate to it two orthogonal ideals: first of 
all we have the orthogonal~$f^{\bot}\subset{\ensuremath{\mathbb{C}}}[t_0,t_1][u_0,u_1]$ that we introduced and used in the 
previous sections; moreover, once we interpret~$f$ as a cubic form~$F$, we have 
also~$F^{\bot} \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{C}}}[v_0,\dotsc,v_3]$, a homogeneous ideal in a polynomial ring in $4$ 
variables, that act on ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{C}}}[z_0,z_1,z_2,z_3]$ by differentiation,
prevtext:
where $X' \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^4$ is a smooth quadric $3$-fold.  In fact, the restriction is 
defined by the quadrics in the ideal of $D_{2,1}$ in $X_{2,1}$.  This space 
of quadrics is $5$-dimensional, and the image is a hyperplane section~$X'$ 
of the Pl\"ucker quadric, defined by the quadratic relation between the 
quadrics in the ideal of $D_{2,1}$ in ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^4$. Consider the closure of the 
graph ${\mathcal Y}\subseteq X_{2,1}\times X' $ of the rational map~$\gamma_{2,1}$. 
The strict transform of~$D_{2,1}$ in~${\mathcal Y}$ is mapped to a 
scroll~$T'$ in~$X'$, the intersection of the secant variety of a Veronese 
surface~$V'$ with the quadric threefold~$X'$. The strict transform in~${
\mathcal Y}$ of~$V_{2,1}$ is mapped to a rational normal quartic curve~$C'$
.   
We now compare the map~$\gamma_{2,1}$ with the rational map $\rho \colon \,  
X_{2,1}\dashrightarrow X_{1,2}$.   Since $\Phi_{2,1}$ is bijective outside 
the preimage of the curve~$D_{2,1}$, the rational map $\rho$ is defined 
outside $D_{2,1}$.  On the other hand $\rho$ is not defined anywhere 
on~$D_{2,1}$.  The Picard group of~$X_{2,1}$ is generated by the hyperplane 
bundle, so the map $\rho$ must be defined by a $5$-dimensional space of 
sections in $H^0({\mathcal I}_{D_{2,1}}(d))$ for some $d$, where ${\mathcal 
I}_{D_{2,1}}$ is the sheaf of ideals of~$D_{2,1}$ on  the quadric $3$-fold $
X_{2,1}$.  To find the degree~$d$ we consider a general curve~$C$ defined 
by a section in~$f^{\bot}_{2,1}$. On the surface $Z_{2,1} \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ the 
curve~$C$ is mapped to a plane quartic curve with a linear pencil of lines 
that cut the curve in the image of schemes of length $4$ that are apolar to~$f$. 
This pencil form a line in~$X_{2,1}$ that does not intersect~$D_{2,1}$. 
Now, the image~$\overline C$ of the curve~$C$ on~$Z_{1,2}$ has degree~$5$. 
The pencil of apolar schemes of length~$4$ on~$C$ are mapped to schemes 
that are collinear also in~$Z_{1,2}$, so they define on~$\overline C$ a 
pencil of $4$-secant  lines.  Assuming $C$ is smooth, any two of these four-
secant lines are disjoint, otherwise $\overline C$ would have a plane 
section of length~$7$ or~$8$, impossible.  Therefore the pencil of $4$-
secant lines are the lines of one family of lines in a smooth quadric 
surface.  This means that the image of this pencil of lines in~$X_{1,2}$ is 
a conic, and hence the degree $d$ is 2. Since $\dim H^0({\mathcal I}_{D_{2,1}}
(2))=5$ we may conclude that the map $\rho$ coincides with~$\gamma_{2,1}$. 
Clearly $\gamma_{1,2}$ is the inverse of~$\gamma_{2,1}$, and the graph~${\mathcal Y}$ 
of~$\rho$ is the blowup of~$X_{2,1}$ along the smooth curve~$D_{2,1}$, 
so ${\mathcal Y}$ is smooth. There is a map from the graph of $
\gamma_{1,2}$ to ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$ which sends a graph point to the ideal 
generated by the two pencils, one in each Grassmannian.  Therefore  the 
graph~${\mathcal Y}$  is identified with the image~$\Xi \bigl( {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4) \bigr)$. 
The graph is smooth, so ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,4)$ and the graph~${\mathcal Y}$ are isomorphic.
\end{proof}

By an analogous procedure to that in the proof of Lemma~\ref{lem:orthogonal_biquadratic}, 
it follows that $f_{2,3}^\bot = T_{0,1} \cdot f_{2,2}^\bot$ and 
$f_{3,2}^\bot = T_{1,0} \cdot f_{2,2}^\bot$, and that $f^\bot$ is generated by
$f_{a,b}^\bot$ for $a,b {\leqslant} 3$ together with~$T_{4,0}$ and~$T_{0,4}$.

We are left to prove that $f_{3,3}^\bot$ is
generated by $f^{\bot}_{2,2}, f^{\bot}_{3,1}, $ and $f^{\bot}_{1,3}$.
If not, then in particular the multiplication map $f^{\bot}_{1,3} \otimes 
T_{2,0}\to f_{3,3}^\bot$, is not onto. But then there is a relation $gq 
- g'q' = 0$, where say $g,g'\in f^{\bot}_{1,3}$, while $q,q'\in T_{2,0}$.  By 
unique factorization, $q$ and $q'$ must have a common factor, so $gl=g'l'$ for 
some $l,l'\in T_{1,0}$. By assumption, $g,g'$ are independent, so $l,l'$ 
generate $T_{1,0}$ and $g=g_0l'$ and $g'=g_0l$.  This is possible only if 
$g_0\in f^{\bot}_{0,3}$, against our assumption.   
\end{proof}

Let $f$ be a general bihomogeneous form of bidegree~$(3,3)$ 
and let  $F \in {\ensuremath{\mathbb{C}}}[z_0,z_1,z_2,z_3]$ be the cubic associated to~$f$. If $F$ is not a cone, the 
orthogonal~$F^{\bot}$ is generated by~$6$ quadrics.   By Sylvester's 
Pentahedral Theorem (see~\cite{Sylvester1904b} and for example~\cite{Oeding2013}*{Theorem~3.9} and
\cite{Landsberg2012}*{Example~12.4.2.3}) the powersum variety 
$\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3} (F, 5)$ is just a point corresponding to a scheme 
$\Gamma_{0} \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ given by a set of~$5$ points.  The ideal of $\Gamma_0$ is generated by $5$ quadrics, so a general quadric apolar to $F$ does not intersect $\Gamma_0$.  In fact we may assume that $\nu_{1,1}( {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}} )$ in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ is defined by a general quadric polynomial orthogonal to $F$, and hence that
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex37.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\dim f_{2,3}^{\bot}\;=\;\dim f_{3,2}^{\bot}\;=\;10,\quad\dim f_{3,3}^{\bot}=15." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>dim</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><msubsup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>⊥</mo></msubsup></mpadded></mrow><mo rspace="5.3pt">=</mo><mrow><mo>dim</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><msubsup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>⊥</mo></msubsup></mpadded></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn> 10</mn></mrow><mo rspace="12.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>dim</mo><mo>⁡</mo><msubsup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>⊥</mo></msubsup></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
We consider the closure $H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0)$ in the Hilbert scheme of twisted cubic curves, of the set of curves that contain $\Gamma_0$.

\begin{proposition}(Kapranov)\cite{Kapranov1993}*{Theorem~4.3.3}\label{H3t+1}
$H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0)$ is isomorphic to a smooth 
 Del Pezzo surface of degree~$5$, i.e. isomorphic to the blowup of~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^2$ in $4$ 
points.
\end{proposition} 

Let $f$ be a general bihomogeneous form of bidegree~$(3,3)$, and let $\Gamma_0$ be the unique set of 
$5$ points in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ that is apolar to the cubic form $F$ corresponding to $f$.
\begin{lemma}
\label{lem:smooth_bicubic}
Let $f$ be a general bihomogeneous form of bidegree~$(3,3)$, and let $\Gamma_0$ be the unique set of 
$5$ points in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ that is apolar to the cubic form $F$ corresponding to $f$. Then for every smooth $\Gamma \in 
{\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$,  there exists a (possibly 
reducible) twisted cubic curve $C_\Gamma$ passing through $\Gamma_0$ and $\Gamma$, in particular $[C_\Gamma]\in H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0)$. 
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}

Consider $6$ general points on $\nu_{1,1}({\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}) \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$.  They are the 
intersection of~$\nu_{1,1}({\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}})$ with a twisted cubic curve. This is a 
particular case of a classical result on~$n+3$ general points in ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^n$, 
attributed to Veronese in~\cite{Cas86}, but often called Castelnuovo's lemma:
\begin{lemma}\label{cast} Through $n+3$ points in ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^n$ no $n$ of which lie in a ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{n-2}$, there is a unique reduced and connected curve of degree $n$ and arithmetic genus $0$.
\end{lemma}

Therefore, if $\Gamma \in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f, 6)$ is an apolar scheme constituted of~$6$ 
general points, then $\Gamma \subseteq C_\Gamma \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$, where 
$C_\Gamma$ is a twisted cubic. By the apolarity lemma, it follows that 
${\ensuremath{\mathnormal{I}}}_\Gamma \subseteq F^\bot$, and since ${\ensuremath{\mathnormal{I}}}_{C_\Gamma} \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathnormal{I}}}_\Gamma$ we 
get ${\ensuremath{\mathnormal{I}}}_{C_\Gamma} \subseteq F^\bot$. One can also show that $\Gamma_0 
\subseteq C_{\Gamma}$. In fact, under the $3$-uple Veronese embedding 
$C_{\Gamma}$ becomes a rational curve of degree~$9$, and since $C_{\Gamma}$ is 
apolar to~$F$, the point~$[F]$ lies in the span of this degree~$9$ curve. 
Therefore $F$ can be interpreted as a general binary form of degree~$9$, and by 
the result of Sylvester (Lemma \ref{rat}), such a binary form has rank~$5$, so $[F]$ lies on the 
span of $5$ points belonging to the degree~$9$ curve. On the other hand, the 
only scheme of $5$ points apolar to~$F$ is $\Gamma_0$, therefore those $5$ 
points are nothing but the image of~$\Gamma_0$ under the $3$-uple Veronese 
embedding, which implies that $C_{\Gamma}$ passes through~$\Gamma_0$.

We consider now the other kinds of smooth schemes in~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$. If no plane 
passes through $4$ of the points of~$\Gamma$, then we are in the general 
situation and the previous argument shows that we have a unique (smooth) twisted 
cubic through~$\Gamma$ and~$\Gamma_0$. Suppose that exactly $4$ points 
of~$\Gamma$ lie on a plane, and no three of them are on a line. Then there is a 
pencil of conics passing through those planar points, and a line~$\ell$ through 
the remaining two points; thus there exists a unique conic~$C$ in this pencil 
meeting~$\ell$. We prove that $\Gamma_0$ is contained in $C \cup \ell$, which 
hence is an element in $H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0) $ (corresponding in the Del Pezzo 
surface  to a point lying on one of the~$10$ lines of the surface). Under the 
$3$-uple Veronese embedding, the line $\ell$ is mapped to a twisted cubic~$D_1$, and the conic $C$ 
is mapped to a rational sextic~$D_2$. By construction, the point~$[F]$ lies on the span 
of~$D_1 \cup D_2$. We denote by~$Q$ the point of intersection between $D_1$ and 
$D_2$.  We use the same technique as in the proof of 
Lemma~\ref{lem:2pencils} to construct a scheme of 
length~$5$ apolar to~$F$. Let $E = {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, D_1$ and $F = {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, D_2$, then $E 
\cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ and $F \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^6$. 
After projection from the point $[F]$ into ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^8$ the two linear spaces $E$ and $F$ will intersect in a line, 
so
there is a unique plane~$P$ containing the line~$\overline{[F] Q}$ and 
intersecting~$E$ in a line~$\ell_E$ and $F$ in a line~$\ell_F$. The variety of 
$3$-secant planes to~$D_2$ is a quartic hypersurface in~$F$, and a general 
line meeting~$D_2$ intersects it in a unique further point.  In particular $\ell_F$ intersects $D_2$ in $Q$ and the variety of 
$3$-secant planes in a further point ~$T$. Therefore we may assume that there are three points~$p_1, p_2$ and $p_3$ in~$D_2$ whose span 
contains~$T$. Consider now the line~$\overline{[F] T}$: since it is 
contained in~$P$, it meets~$\ell_E$ in one point~$R$. A general point 
in~$E$ lies in a unique secant to~$D_1$, so we obtain two points $p_4, p_5$ 
in~$D_2$ whose span contains~$R$. In this way $[F] \in {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \bigl( \{p_1, 
\dotsc, p_5\} \bigr)$.  As above $\{p_1, \dotsc, p_5\} = \Gamma_0$ under 
the $3$-uple Veronese embedding, so the lemma follows also in this case. 

Eventually, we rule out all the cases that are left. Suppose in fact that $3$ of 
the $6$ points of~$\Gamma$ are collinear on a line~$\ell$, or~$5$ of the~$6$ 
points lie in a plane. In the first case, the three collinear points may be 
replaced in~$\Gamma$ by a scheme of length~$2$, so that $f$ is apolar to a 
scheme of length~$5$ on~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$. In the second case, the five coplanar points may 
be replaced in~$\Gamma$ by a scheme of length~$4$, so that $f$ is apolar to a 
scheme of length~$5$ on~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$. In both cases this is against the generality 
assumption of~$f$.
\end{proof}

We now reformulate and prove Theorem \ref{B}.
\begin{theorem}
\label{bicubictheorem}
For a general bihomogeneous form $f$ of bidegree~$(3,3)$ the variety~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$  is isomorphic to a smooth Del Pezzo surface of degree~$5$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
Let $\Gamma_0$ be the set of $5$ points apolar to the cubic form $F$ associated to $f$ as in Lemma \ref{lem:smooth_bicubic}.
Let $H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0)$ be the Hilbert scheme of twisted cubic curves 
through $\Gamma_0$. 

If $[C]\in H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0)$, then $C$ is a cubic curve through~$\Gamma_0$, 
that is apolar to~$F$. Moreover $\nu_{1,1}( {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}} ) \cap C$ is a scheme of length 
$6$.  In fact every component of $C$ contains some subset of~$\Gamma_0$ and 
therefore intersects $\nu_{1,1}( {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}} )$ properly.

Thus, we get a morphism
prevtext:
By an analogous procedure to that in the proof of Lemma~\ref{lem:orthogonal_biquadratic}, 
it follows that $f_{2,3}^\bot = T_{0,1} \cdot f_{2,2}^\bot$ and 
$f_{3,2}^\bot = T_{1,0} \cdot f_{2,2}^\bot$, and that $f^\bot$ is generated by
$f_{a,b}^\bot$ for $a,b {\leqslant} 3$ together with~$T_{4,0}$ and~$T_{0,4}$.

We are left to prove that $f_{3,3}^\bot$ is
generated by $f^{\bot}_{2,2}, f^{\bot}_{3,1}, $ and $f^{\bot}_{1,3}$.
If not, then in particular the multiplication map $f^{\bot}_{1,3} \otimes 
T_{2,0}\to f_{3,3}^\bot$, is not onto. But then there is a relation $gq 
- g'q' = 0$, where say $g,g'\in f^{\bot}_{1,3}$, while $q,q'\in T_{2,0}$.  By 
unique factorization, $q$ and $q'$ must have a common factor, so $gl=g'l'$ for 
some $l,l'\in T_{1,0}$. By assumption, $g,g'$ are independent, so $l,l'$ 
generate $T_{1,0}$ and $g=g_0l'$ and $g'=g_0l$.  This is possible only if 
$g_0\in f^{\bot}_{0,3}$, against our assumption.   
\end{proof}

Let $f$ be a general bihomogeneous form of bidegree~$(3,3)$ 
and let  $F \in {\ensuremath{\mathbb{C}}}[z_0,z_1,z_2,z_3]$ be the cubic associated to~$f$. If $F$ is not a cone, the 
orthogonal~$F^{\bot}$ is generated by~$6$ quadrics.   By Sylvester's 
Pentahedral Theorem (see~\cite{Sylvester1904b} and for example~\cite{Oeding2013}*{Theorem~3.9} and
\cite{Landsberg2012}*{Example~12.4.2.3}) the powersum variety 
$\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3} (F, 5)$ is just a point corresponding to a scheme 
$\Gamma_{0} \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ given by a set of~$5$ points.  The ideal of $\Gamma_0$ is generated by $5$ quadrics, so a general quadric apolar to $F$ does not intersect $\Gamma_0$.  In fact we may assume that $\nu_{1,1}( {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}} )$ in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ is defined by a general quadric polynomial orthogonal to $F$, and hence that
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex38.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Gamma_{0}\cap\nu_{1,1}({{\mathbb{P}}^{1}\times{\mathbb{P}}^{1}})=\emptyset." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>∩</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ν</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>ℙ</mi><mn>1</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><msup><mi>ℙ</mi><mn>1</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∅</mi></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
