This morphism is injective, because otherwise there would be two cubic curves~$C$ and~$C'$ 
that pass through $\Gamma_0$ and have a common intersection 
with $\nu_{1,1}\left( {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}} \right)$. Since $\Gamma_0$ has no common point with $\nu_{1,1} \left( 
{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}} \right)$ this is impossible by Castelnuovo's lemma. To show that the morphism $\psi$ is surjective, we 
first note that both $H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0)$ and the variety ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$ are surfaces, so it suffices to 
show that $\psi$ is onto the set of smooth schemes in~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$. This is 
precisely the content of Lemma~\ref{lem:smooth_bicubic}.

It remains to show that the bijective morphism $\psi$ is an isomorphism. 

\begin{lemma}\label{all6apolar} If $f$ is a general $(3,3)$-form and $[\Gamma]\in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$ then $\Gamma$ is apolar to $f$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}  
The ideal of each curve~$C$ in~$H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0)$ is contained in the ideal of~$\Gamma_0$ and is therefore apolar to the cubic form~$F$ associated to~$f$.  The scheme of intersection $\nu_{1,1}( {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}} )\cap C$ is therefore apolar to~$f$.  This intersection has length~$6$ and belongs to the closure of the smooth apolar schemes in~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$.  Since $\psi$ is a surjective  morphism, the lemma follows. 
\end{proof}

To show that $\psi$ is an isomorphism, we show that ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$ is smooth.  First of all, the Hilbert scheme ${\ensuremath\mathrm{Hilb}}_6({\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}})$ itself is smooth (see~\cite{Fogarty1968}).
Consider next, in~${\ensuremath\mathrm{Hilb}}_6({\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}})$, the open subset~${\mathcal U}$ of schemes that lie on a unique curve in the Hilbert scheme of twisted cubic curves in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$, and whose ideal on ${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$ has $\dim I_{\Gamma,(3,3)}=10$, or equivalently, such that the span of~$\nu_{3,3}{\Gamma}$ is a~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$.  Over ${\mathcal U}$ we consider the rank $10$ vector bundle~$E_{\mathcal U}$ whose fibre over a scheme~$[\Gamma]$ is the dual of the space $I_{\Gamma,3,3} \subseteq T_{(3,3)}$ of $(3,3)$ forms in the ideal of $\Gamma$. The linear form $\phi_{f,(3,3)} \colon T_{(3,3)}\to {\ensuremath{\mathbb{C}}}$ defines a section on~$E_{\mathcal U}$.  If ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6) \subseteq {\mathcal U}$, then ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$ is the $0$-locus of this section, by Lemma \ref{all6apolar}.
\begin{lemma}If $f\in S_{3,3}$ is general, then ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)\subseteq {\mathcal U}$.
\end{lemma} 
\begin{proof}  It suffices to prove that for any $[\Gamma]\in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$ the span of~$\nu_{3,3}(\Gamma)$ is a~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$.  For a general~$f$, consider the $5$ points~$\Gamma_0$ apolar to the cubic form~$F$ on~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ associated to $f$.   We may assume that every line through a pair of points of~$\Gamma_0$ intersects~$\nu_{1,1}\left({\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}\right)$ transversally.  Therefore the intersection of any cubic curve in $H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0)$ with $\nu_{1,1}\left({\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}\right)$ is curvilinear.  If the cubic curve has a component of degree $d$, then the intersection with $\nu_{1,1}\left({\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}\right)$ has degree~$2d$.  On the $3$-uple embedding of this curve, any such curvilinear scheme spans a ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^5$.
\end{proof}
 
 The space of forms $\phi_{f,(3,3)}$ form a linear space ($=S_{(3,3)}$) of sections of $E_{\mathcal U}$ without  basepoints on ${\mathcal U}$, 
so for a general $f$ the $0$-locus ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$ is smooth.
Since $\psi$ is a bijective map between smooth surfaces, it is an isomorphism.
\end{proof}

\section{Cubic forms on a cubic surface scroll}\label{cubicone}

Let $\Sigma$ be a cubic scroll in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^4$.


The Picard group ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{Pic}}}(\Sigma)$ is free of rank $2$ generated by the class of curves $E$ and $F$, where $E^2=-1,\, E\cdot F=1$ and $F^2=0$. The linear system $|E+F|$ defines a morphism $\pi \colon \Sigma\to {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^2$, which is the blowup of a point $p_E\in {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^2$ with exceptional divisor $\pi^{-1}(p_E)=E$.  The Cox ring of $\Sigma$ is isomorphic to a 
bihomogeneous polynomial ring $S={\ensuremath{\mathbb{C}}}[x_0,x_1,y_0,y_1]$ such that
prevtext:
We consider the closure $H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0)$ in the Hilbert scheme of twisted cubic curves, of the set of curves that contain $\Gamma_0$.

\begin{proposition}(Kapranov)\cite{Kapranov1993}*{Theorem~4.3.3}\label{H3t+1}
$H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0)$ is isomorphic to a smooth 
 Del Pezzo surface of degree~$5$, i.e. isomorphic to the blowup of~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^2$ in $4$ 
points.
\end{proposition} 

Let $f$ be a general bihomogeneous form of bidegree~$(3,3)$, and let $\Gamma_0$ be the unique set of 
$5$ points in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ that is apolar to the cubic form $F$ corresponding to $f$.
\begin{lemma}
\label{lem:smooth_bicubic}
Let $f$ be a general bihomogeneous form of bidegree~$(3,3)$, and let $\Gamma_0$ be the unique set of 
$5$ points in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ that is apolar to the cubic form $F$ corresponding to $f$. Then for every smooth $\Gamma \in 
{\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$,  there exists a (possibly 
reducible) twisted cubic curve $C_\Gamma$ passing through $\Gamma_0$ and $\Gamma$, in particular $[C_\Gamma]\in H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0)$. 
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}

Consider $6$ general points on $\nu_{1,1}({\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}) \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$.  They are the 
intersection of~$\nu_{1,1}({\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}})$ with a twisted cubic curve. This is a 
particular case of a classical result on~$n+3$ general points in ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^n$, 
attributed to Veronese in~\cite{Cas86}, but often called Castelnuovo's lemma:
\begin{lemma}\label{cast} Through $n+3$ points in ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^n$ no $n$ of which lie in a ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{n-2}$, there is a unique reduced and connected curve of degree $n$ and arithmetic genus $0$.
\end{lemma}

Therefore, if $\Gamma \in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VSP}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f, 6)$ is an apolar scheme constituted of~$6$ 
general points, then $\Gamma \subseteq C_\Gamma \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$, where 
$C_\Gamma$ is a twisted cubic. By the apolarity lemma, it follows that 
${\ensuremath{\mathnormal{I}}}_\Gamma \subseteq F^\bot$, and since ${\ensuremath{\mathnormal{I}}}_{C_\Gamma} \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathnormal{I}}}_\Gamma$ we 
get ${\ensuremath{\mathnormal{I}}}_{C_\Gamma} \subseteq F^\bot$. One can also show that $\Gamma_0 
\subseteq C_{\Gamma}$. In fact, under the $3$-uple Veronese embedding 
$C_{\Gamma}$ becomes a rational curve of degree~$9$, and since $C_{\Gamma}$ is 
apolar to~$F$, the point~$[F]$ lies in the span of this degree~$9$ curve. 
Therefore $F$ can be interpreted as a general binary form of degree~$9$, and by 
the result of Sylvester (Lemma \ref{rat}), such a binary form has rank~$5$, so $[F]$ lies on the 
span of $5$ points belonging to the degree~$9$ curve. On the other hand, the 
only scheme of $5$ points apolar to~$F$ is $\Gamma_0$, therefore those $5$ 
points are nothing but the image of~$\Gamma_0$ under the $3$-uple Veronese 
embedding, which implies that $C_{\Gamma}$ passes through~$\Gamma_0$.

We consider now the other kinds of smooth schemes in~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$. If no plane 
passes through $4$ of the points of~$\Gamma$, then we are in the general 
situation and the previous argument shows that we have a unique (smooth) twisted 
cubic through~$\Gamma$ and~$\Gamma_0$. Suppose that exactly $4$ points 
of~$\Gamma$ lie on a plane, and no three of them are on a line. Then there is a 
pencil of conics passing through those planar points, and a line~$\ell$ through 
the remaining two points; thus there exists a unique conic~$C$ in this pencil 
meeting~$\ell$. We prove that $\Gamma_0$ is contained in $C \cup \ell$, which 
hence is an element in $H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0) $ (corresponding in the Del Pezzo 
surface  to a point lying on one of the~$10$ lines of the surface). Under the 
$3$-uple Veronese embedding, the line $\ell$ is mapped to a twisted cubic~$D_1$, and the conic $C$ 
is mapped to a rational sextic~$D_2$. By construction, the point~$[F]$ lies on the span 
of~$D_1 \cup D_2$. We denote by~$Q$ the point of intersection between $D_1$ and 
$D_2$.  We use the same technique as in the proof of 
Lemma~\ref{lem:2pencils} to construct a scheme of 
length~$5$ apolar to~$F$. Let $E = {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, D_1$ and $F = {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \, D_2$, then $E 
\cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^3$ and $F \cong {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^6$. 
After projection from the point $[F]$ into ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^8$ the two linear spaces $E$ and $F$ will intersect in a line, 
so
there is a unique plane~$P$ containing the line~$\overline{[F] Q}$ and 
intersecting~$E$ in a line~$\ell_E$ and $F$ in a line~$\ell_F$. The variety of 
$3$-secant planes to~$D_2$ is a quartic hypersurface in~$F$, and a general 
line meeting~$D_2$ intersects it in a unique further point.  In particular $\ell_F$ intersects $D_2$ in $Q$ and the variety of 
$3$-secant planes in a further point ~$T$. Therefore we may assume that there are three points~$p_1, p_2$ and $p_3$ in~$D_2$ whose span 
contains~$T$. Consider now the line~$\overline{[F] T}$: since it is 
contained in~$P$, it meets~$\ell_E$ in one point~$R$. A general point 
in~$E$ lies in a unique secant to~$D_1$, so we obtain two points $p_4, p_5$ 
in~$D_2$ whose span contains~$R$. In this way $[F] \in {\ensuremath\mathrm{span}} \bigl( \{p_1, 
\dotsc, p_5\} \bigr)$.  As above $\{p_1, \dotsc, p_5\} = \Gamma_0$ under 
the $3$-uple Veronese embedding, so the lemma follows also in this case. 

Eventually, we rule out all the cases that are left. Suppose in fact that $3$ of 
the $6$ points of~$\Gamma$ are collinear on a line~$\ell$, or~$5$ of the~$6$ 
points lie in a plane. In the first case, the three collinear points may be 
replaced in~$\Gamma$ by a scheme of length~$2$, so that $f$ is apolar to a 
scheme of length~$5$ on~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$. In the second case, the five coplanar points may 
be replaced in~$\Gamma$ by a scheme of length~$4$, so that $f$ is apolar to a 
scheme of length~$5$ on~${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}$. In both cases this is against the generality 
assumption of~$f$.
\end{proof}

We now reformulate and prove Theorem \ref{B}.
\begin{theorem}
\label{bicubictheorem}
For a general bihomogeneous form $f$ of bidegree~$(3,3)$ the variety~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{{\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}}}}}(f,6)$  is isomorphic to a smooth Del Pezzo surface of degree~$5$.
\end{theorem}

through $\Gamma_0$. 

If $[C]\in H_{3t+1}(\Gamma_0)$, then $C$ is a cubic curve through~$\Gamma_0$, 
that is apolar to~$F$. Moreover $\nu_{1,1}( {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}} ) \cap C$ is a scheme of length 
$6$.  In fact every component of $C$ contains some subset of~$\Gamma_0$ and 
therefore intersects $\nu_{1,1}( {\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1\times{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^1}} )$ properly.

Thus, we get a morphism

has maximal rank, so $I_{f,2E+3F}= \ker \phi_{f,2E+3F}$ is $2$-dimensional, i.e. defines a pencil~of curves~in $K \subseteq |2E+3F|$. 
 Notice that, by the apolarity lemma~\ref{apolarity}, every curve in $K$ is apolar to $f$.
 \begin{lemma}  For a general $f\in S_{3E+6F}$, the singular curves in $K$ are irreducible nodal curves and the basepoints $\Gamma_0$  of $K$ are $8$ general points in~$\Sigma$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}   Let $\Gamma_0 \subseteq \Sigma$ be $8$ general points.  In degree $2E+3F$, the ideal of~$\Gamma_0$ is $2$-dimensional.
Furthermore, the set of forms $f'\in S_{3E+6F}$ for which $\Gamma_0$ is apolar is the $7$-dimensional subspace in $S_{3E+6F}$ orthogonal to $I_{\Gamma_0,{3E+6F}} \subseteq T_{3E+6F}$.    These $f'$ are precisely the forms that are apolar to every curve in~$K$.
Now, ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}(S_{3E+6F})$ has dimension~$21$, while the set of pencils in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}(T_{2E+3F})$ has dimension~$14$, so the general pencil is apolar to some form~$f$ and the lemma follows.
 \end{proof}

Now any scheme~$\Gamma$ in~$\mathrm{VSP}_{\Sigma}(f,8)$ has length $8$, so it lies in a curve in 
$|2E+3F|$.  Therefore, if $\Gamma$ is apolar, it lies 
in a curve in~$K$.  Now the base scheme~$\Gamma_0$ of $K$ has
length~$8$, so this scheme is the only one of length $8$ that lies on all curves in $K$.  
The other schemes $\Gamma \subseteq C \subseteq \Sigma$ of length $8$ that are apolar to $f$ lies in a unique curve $C\in K$.  

Let $C\in K$.  Then $C$ is apolar to $f$, so may consider the variety
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex46.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\phi_{f,2E+3F}\colon T_{2E+3F}\to S_{E+3F}" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>ϕ</mi><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>E</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><mrow><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>E</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
such that the restriction of $\psi_f$ to ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{C}}}(f,8)$ coincides with $\psi_C$ for each $C\in K$.

We proceed to show that $\psi_C$ is an isomorphism for every curve $C\in K$.
For this we first give a more general fact for elliptic curves, equivalent to Lemma~\ref{elliptic}.
\begin{lemma} \label{ell} 
Let $C \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{2d-2}$ be an elliptic normal curve of degree~$2d-1$, then 
the set of $d$-secant ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{d-1}$'s to~$C$ that pass though a general point 
in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{2d-2}$, correspond one to one to points on~$C$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Let $C$ be an elliptic normal curve of degree~$2d$ embedded 
by a line bundle~$\mathcal{L}$, then the $d-1$-secant variety of~$C$ is a 
complete intersection of a pencil of determinantal hypersurfaces of degree~$d$, 
that each are defined by a pair of line bundles of degree $d$ that add 
up to~$\mathcal{L}$ (see~\cite{Fisher}*{Theorem~1.3, Lemma~2.9}, \cite{Room}). 
 Furthermore,  for a general line that intersects~$C$ in a point~$q$, every point 
outside~$C$ lies on a unique hypersurface in the pencil, so after projection the 
curve~$C$ from~$q$ has degree~$2d-1$ and through a general point the 
$d$-secants correspond one to one to  line bundles of degree~$d$ on~$C$, i.e.\ 
one to one to points on~$C$.
\end{proof}
\begin{lemma} Assume $f$ is general, so that the singular curves in $K$ are irreducible and nodal and that the basepoints  $\Gamma_0$ of $K$  are $8$ points disjoint from $E$.  Then the morphism $\psi_C \colon \mathrm{VSP}_{C}(f,8)\to C$ is an isomophism for every $C\in K$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof} Consider the embedding $C\to {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{14}\subset{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}(S_{3E+6F})$ defined by the linear system $|(3E+6F)_C|$ of divisors on $C$, defined by the linear system of curves $|3E+6F|$ restricted to $C$.  It is the composition of the embedding defined by $|4E+6F|$ and the projection from the point $E\cap C$.   We consider Weil and Cartier divisors on $C$ (if $C$ is smooth they of course coincide).  While Weil divisors may have multiplicity one at a node $p_C$ of $C$,  any effective Cartier divisor has multiplicity at least two at $p_C$. Any Weil divisor $\Gamma$ of degree $8$ on $C$ is contained in a unique Cartier divisor $\bar\Gamma$ of degree $9$ defined on $C$ by the pencil $D_\Gamma$ of curves  in $|3E+3F|$ that contain $\Gamma$.  The uniqueness of~$D_\Gamma$, implies both that the map $\psi_C \colon \Gamma\mapsto p_\Gamma=\bar\Gamma -\Gamma$ is well-defined, and that it is injective as soon as there is a unique divisor in the linear system in $|(3E+3F)_C-p_\Gamma|$ in~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{C}}}(f,8)$.
Any curve~$G_\Gamma$ in $|4E+6F|$ that is not a multiple of $C$ and contains the Cartier divisor~$\bar\Gamma$, defines on~$C$ a Weil divisor $\Gamma'=G_\Gamma\cap C-\Gamma$ of degree $8$ that contains the point $p_\Gamma$.    Thus $\Gamma+\Gamma'$ is a hyperplane section of $C \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{15}\subset{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}(S_{4E+6F})$ and define a pair of linear systems
prevtext: Clearly the restriction of $\psi$ to ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{C}}}(f,8)$ extends to the morphism $\psi_{C}$ for every curve $C\in K$.  Since $\psi_{C}(\Gamma_0)=\pi(E)$ for each $C$, and every other~$\Gamma$ in~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{\Sigma}}}(f,8)$ lies in a unique $C$, we see that the restriction of~$\psi$ to~${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{\Sigma}}}(f,8)$ extends to a morphism
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex51.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\psi_{f}\colon{\mathrm{VPS}_{\Sigma}}(f,8)\to{\mathbb{P}}^{2}" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>:</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>VPS</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>→</mo><msup><mi>ℙ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
like in the Lemma \ref{ell} above for smooth elliptic curves.  
Since $\Gamma+\Gamma'\equiv (4E+6F)_C$, and $\Gamma+p_\Gamma\equiv(3E+3F)_C$, we get
$\Gamma'-p_\Gamma\equiv(E+3F)_C$, i.e. $\Gamma'\equiv(E+3F)_C+p_\Gamma$.  Now, $|(E+3F)_C+p|=|(E+3F)_C+p'|$ if and only if  $|(F)_C+p|=|(F)_C+p'|$ which again is equivalent to $p=p'$.
Therefore the linear system $L_\Gamma$ is uniquely defined by $p_\Gamma$.

A general point in ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{15}$ lies in the span of a unique divisor in each of these linear systems of degree $8$. 
So, after projection from the point $E\cap C$, through a general point $[f]\in {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{14}$ in the span of $C \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{14}\subset{\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}(S_{3E+6F})$, the set of subschemes $\Gamma$ of length $8$ on $C$ whose span contains~$[f]$ are in one to one correspondence with linear systems $L_\Gamma$ and hence of the points~$p_\Gamma$
 on~$C$.  And the correspondence coincides with the map $\psi_C \colon {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{C}}}(f,8)\to C$ above.
\end{proof}

Every $[\Gamma]\in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{\Sigma}}}(f,8)$ belongs to ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{C}}}(f,8)$ for some $C\in K$, so in particular, every $[\Gamma]\in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{\Sigma}}}(f,8)$ is apolar to $f$.  
Consider therefore the open subset ${\mathcal U'} \subseteq {\mathcal U} \subseteq {\ensuremath\mathrm{Hilb}}_8 (\Sigma)$ of the smooth open set ${\mathcal U}$ above consisting of schemes $\Gamma$, such that $\dim I_{\Gamma,(3E+6F)}=18$, or equivalently, such that $\nu_{3E+6F}(\Gamma)$ spans a ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^7$.  Let $E_{\mathcal U}$ be the  vector bundle of rank $18$ over ${\mathcal U}$ whose fiber over $[\Gamma]$ is the dual of the space of sections in degree $3E+6F$ of the ideal $I_{\Gamma, (3E+6F)} \subseteq T_{3E+6F}$.  The linear form $\phi_{f,(3E+6F)} \colon T_{(3,3)}\to {\ensuremath{\mathbb{C}}}$ defines a section on $E_{\mathcal U}$. If ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{\Sigma}}}(f,8) \subseteq {\mathcal U'}$, then ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{\Sigma}}}(f,8)$ is the $0$-locus of this section, since any $\Gamma$ in ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{\Sigma}}}(f,8)$ is apolar to $f$.  
\begin{lemma} If $f\in S_{3E+6F}$ is general, then ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{\Sigma}}}(f,8) \subseteq {\mathcal U'}$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
It suffices to show that for any $[\Gamma]\in {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{\Sigma}}}(f,8)$ the image $\nu_{3E+6F}(\Gamma)$ spans a ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^7$.  But this follows from the above, since $\Gamma \subseteq C$ for some irreducible curve~$C$ in~$K$, and any subscheme of length $8$ on the curve $\nu_{3E+6F}(C)$ spans a ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^7$.
\end{proof}

The space of forms $\phi_{f,(3E+6F)}$ form a linear space ($=S_{(3E+6F)}$) of sections of $E_{\mathcal U}$ without  basepoints on ${\mathcal U}$, 
so for a general $f$ the $0$-locus ${\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{\Sigma}}}(f,8)$ is smooth.

Now, every point outside~$\Gamma_0$ lies in a unique curve $C\in K$, so $\psi_f$ is a birational morphism from a smooth surface and has an inverse that is defined outside~$\pi(\Gamma_0)$.
Let $\pi' \colon \Sigma'\to {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^2$ be the blowup along~$\pi(\Gamma_0)$.  Since, by assumption, all $C\in K$ are smooth at~$\Gamma_0$, the inverse map to $\psi_f$ lifts to a morphism  $\psi_f' \colon \Sigma'\to {\ensuremath{\mathrm{VPS}_{\Sigma}}}(f,8)$  that restricts to the inverse of~$\psi_C$ on the strict transform of~$\pi(C)$ on~$\Sigma'$.
Therefore $\psi_f'$ is an inverse of~$\psi_f$, and hence an isomorphism.
\end{proof}

We proceed to show that $\psi_C$ is an isomorphism for every curve $C\in K$.
For this we first give a more general fact for elliptic curves, equivalent to Lemma~\ref{elliptic}.
\begin{lemma} \label{ell} 
Let $C \subseteq {\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{2d-2}$ be an elliptic normal curve of degree~$2d-1$, then 
the set of $d$-secant ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{d-1}$'s to~$C$ that pass though a general point 
in~${\ensuremath{\mathbb{P}}}^{2d-2}$, correspond one to one to points on~$C$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Let $C$ be an elliptic normal curve of degree~$2d$ embedded 
by a line bundle~$\mathcal{L}$, then the $d-1$-secant variety of~$C$ is a 
complete intersection of a pencil of determinantal hypersurfaces of degree~$d$, 
that each are defined by a pair of line bundles of degree $d$ that add 
up to~$\mathcal{L}$ (see~\cite{Fisher}*{Theorem~1.3, Lemma~2.9}, \cite{Room}). 
 Furthermore,  for a general line that intersects~$C$ in a point~$q$, every point 
outside~$C$ lies on a unique hypersurface in the pencil, so after projection the 
curve~$C$ from~$q$ has degree~$2d-1$ and through a general point the 
$d$-secants correspond one to one to  line bundles of degree~$d$ on~$C$, i.e.\ 
one to one to points on~$C$.
\end{proof}
\begin{lemma} Assume $f$ is general, so that the singular curves in $K$ are irreducible and nodal and that the basepoints  $\Gamma_0$ of $K$  are $8$ points disjoint from $E$.  Then the morphism $\psi_C \colon \mathrm{VSP}_{C}(f,8)\to C$ is an isomophism for every $C\in K$.
\end{lemma}

It is the composition of the embedding defined by $|4E+6F|$ and the projection from the point $E\cap C$.   We consider Weil and Cartier divisors on $C$ (if $C$ is smooth they of course coincide).  While Weil divisors may have multiplicity one at a node $p_C$ of $C$,  any effective Cartier divisor has multiplicity at least two at $p_C$.
